{{italic title}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = ''Koninkrijksdag'' |type = |image = |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = [[The Kingdom of the Netherlands]] ([[Netherlands]], [[Aruba]], [[Curaçao]], and [[Sint Maarten]]) |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = The commemoration of the signing of the [[Charter of the Kingdom of the Netherlands]] |begins = |ends = |date = 15 December
(If a Sunday, on Monday 16 December) |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual }} [[File:Flag of the Netherlands.svg|thumb|[[Flag of the Netherlands]]]] '''''Koninkrijksdag''''' ({{lang-pap|Dia di Reino}}, {{lang-en|Kingdom Day}}, [[West Frisian language|West Frisian]]: ''Keninkryksdei'') is the commemoration of the signing of the [[Charter for the Kingdom of the Netherlands]] on 15 December 1954 in [[Aruba]], [[Curaçao]], the [[Netherlands]], and [[Sint Maarten]].{{nl icon}} [http://www.postbus51.nl/nl/home/themas/overheid-en-democratie/organisatie-van-de-overheid/nederlandse-antillen-en-aruba/wat-is-de-relatie-tussen-nederland-de-nederlandse-antillen-en-aruba.html Wat is de relatie tussen Nederland, de Nederlandse Antillen en Aruba?]. Postbus 51. Retrieved on 2009-07-10. When 15 December falls on a Sunday, the commemoration takes place on Monday 16 December. Kingdom Day is, unlike ''[[Koningsdag]]'' ({{lang-en|King's Day}}), not an official [[public holiday|national holiday]], but government buildings are instructed to fly the [[flag of the Netherlands]].{{cn|date=December 2017}} The Charter for the Kingdom of the Netherlands was signed by [[Juliana of the Netherlands|Queen Juliana]] on 15 December 1954.{{cn|date=December 2017}} The charter deals with the relation between the Netherlands and the overseas territories, the [[Netherlands Antilles]], [[Netherlands New Guinea]] and [[Suriname]]. As of 2010, the charter governs the relationships between the Netherlands, Aruba (since 1986), Curaçao and Sint Maarten (since 2010). Since 2005, the ''Koninkrijksconcert'' ({{lang-en|Kingdom Concert}}) is annually held on 15 December, to celebrate the relationship between Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles, and Aruba.{{nl icon}} [http://www.minbzk.nl/onderwerpen/de-nederlandse/nieuwe-staatkundige/nieuws--en?ActItmIdt=63867 Koningin bij eerste Koninkrijksconcert in Dordrecht] (2005-11-22). [[Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]]. Retrieved on 2009-07-10. At the concerts, that were held in respectively [[Dordrecht]], [[Amersfoort]], [[Nijmegen]], and [[Curaçao]], musical artists from all over the kingdom have performed.{{nl icon}} [http://www.minbzk.nl/actueel?ActItmIdt=109766 Prof. mr. Pieter van Vollenhoven bezoekt Koninkrijksconcert] (2007-12-05). [[Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]]. Retrieved on 2009-07-10.{{nl icon}} [http://www.minbzk.nl/organisatie/staatssecretaris/blindganger/video%27s/video%27s-bijleveld?ActItmIdt=116199 Koninkrijksconcert 2008 vanuit Curaçao]. [[Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]]. Retrieved on 2009-07-10. In 2008, ''Naturalisatiedag'' ({{lang-en|Naturalisation Day}}) in the Kingdom of the Netherlands was moved from 24 August, the day on which the [[Constitution of the Netherlands]] was signed, to 15 December, which has a symbolic meaning for all constituent countries of the kingdom. On Naturalisation Day, newly naturalized citizens officially receive their [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|Dutch]] [[citizenship]].{{nl icon}} [http://static.rnw.nl/migratie/antilliaans.caribiana.nl/innederland/car20080301_naturalisatie-15dec-redirected Koninkrijksdag wordt naturalisatiedag]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. [[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]. Retrieved on 2009-07-10. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Dutch monarchy]] [[Category:Dutch society]] [[Category:December observances]]

page.title: List of Finnish monarchs and Heads of State

revision.text:
{{for|the Swedish & Russian names where applicable|List of Swedish monarchs|List of Russian rulers}} This is a '''list of the monarchs of [[Finland]]''' until it became a republic in 1919; that is, the [[monarch|King]]s of [[Sweden]] with [[Regent]]s and [[Viceroy]]s of the [[Kalmar Union]], the [[Grand Duke of Finland|Grand Dukes of Finland]], a title used by most Swedish monarchs, up to the two-year Regent period following the independence in 1917, with [[Kingdom of Finland (1918)|a brief flirtation with a truly domestic monarchy]].
==Part of the Kingdom of Sweden, from the High Middle Ages until 1809==
''Finland as an integral part of Sweden under the [[King of Sweden]] (Ruotsin kuningas).''
Some texts suggest the Swedish rule of Finland started as early as during the Houses of Sverker and Eric ([[Sverker I of Sweden]] 1130–1156 and [[Eric the Saint]] 1156–1160). But the first historic documents suggesting rule by Swedish kings in Finland not limited to sparse crusades and conquests are dated at around 1249.
===The [[House of Bjelbo]]=== *1250–1275 : [[Valdemar, King of Sweden|Valdemar I]] (''Valdemar Birgerinpoika'') **regent: [[Birger Jarl]] *1275–1284 : [[Magnus III of Sweden|Magnus I]] (''Maunu I Ladonlukko'') *1284–1291 : [[Benedict, Duke of Finland|Benedict I]] (''Bengt Birgerinpoika '') *1291–1302 : [[Birger, King of Sweden|Birger]] (''Birger Maununpoika'') *1302–1319 : [[Valdemar, Duke of Finland|Valdemar II]] (''Valdemar Maununpoika'') and his first wife *1319–1353 : [[Ingeborg Eriksdottir of Norway]], widow of Valdemar II *1353–1356 : [[Benedict, Duke of Halland|Benedict II]] (''Pentti Algotinpoika'') *1357-1359 : [[Eric XII of Sweden|Eric I]] *1359 : [[Magnus IV of Sweden|Magnus II]] (''Maunu II'') and [[Eric XII of Sweden|Eric I]] *1359–1364 : [[Magnus IV of Sweden|Magnus II]] (''Maunu II'') and [[Haakon I of Sweden|Haakon]], sons of Magnus II
===The [[House of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]]===
*1364–1395 : [[Albert, King of Sweden]] (''Albrekt Mecklenburgilainen'')
===Rulers of the [[Kalmar Union]] and Regents (''Valtionhoitaja'', ''Riksföreståndare'')=== [[File:Karl Knutsson Bonde.jpg|thumb|100px|Karl Knutsson Bonde]]
*1389–1412 : [[Margaret I of Denmark]] (''Margareeta''), widow of King Haakon of Sweden, mother of Olav IV, and heiress of [[Estonia]], a Danish dominion *1412–1439 : [[Eric XIII of Sweden|Eric II]] (''Eerik XIII Pommerilainen'', died 1459), a first cousin twice removed of Haakon I of Sweden *1438–1440 : [[Charles VIII of Sweden|Carl Knutsson Bonde, Regent]] (''Kaarle Knuutinpoika'') *1441–1448 : [[Christopher of Bavaria]] (''Kristoffer Baijerilainen'') *1448–1448 : Regents [[Bengt and Nils Oxenstierna of Sweden|Bengt and Nils Jönsson Oxenstierna]] ((''Pentti Jönsinpoika Häräntähti'' and ''Niilo Jönsinpoika Häräntähti'')) *1448–1457 : [[Charles VIII of Sweden|Charles I]] (''Kaarle I Knuutinpoika''), he had been 1442–48 chatelain and [[margrave of Viipuri]] county *1457–1457 : Regents [[John Oxenstierna of Sweden|Jöns Bengtsson Oxenstierna]] the archbishop and [[Eric Tott of Sweden|Eric Axelsson Tott]] ((arkkipiispa ''Jöns Pentinpoika'' and herra ''Eerik Akselinpoika'')) *1457–1464 : [[Christian I of Sweden]] (''Kristian I'') *1464–1470 : [[Charles VIII of Sweden|Charles I]] (restored) *1470–1497 : Regent [[Sten Sture the elder of Sweden|Sten Sture the elder]] (''Sten Sture vanhempi'') - also, 1483–1501 chatelain and margrave of Viipuri county *1497–1501 : [[John II of Sweden|John I]] (''Juhana I'') *1501–1503 : Regent [[Sten Sture the elder of Sweden|Sten Sture the elder]] (''Sten Sture vanhempi'') *1504–1511 : Regent [[Svante of Sweden|Svante Nisson]] (''Svante Niilonpoika, Ekesiön herra'', he did not use the name of Sture) *1512–1512 : Regent [[Eric Trolle of Sweden|Eric Trolle]] *1512–1520 : Regent [[Sten Sture the younger of Sweden|Sten Sture the younger]] (''Sten Sture nuorempi'', he took the name of Sture of his great-grandmother's family, for image reasons and for its prestige) *1520–1521 : [[Christian II of Sweden]] (''Kristian II'')
===The [[House of Vasa]]=== [[File:John III of Sweden.jpg|thumb|100px|Juhana III]]
*1521–1556 : [[Gustav I of Sweden|Gustav I]] (''Kustaa I Vaasa'') *1556–1563 : [[John III of Sweden|John II]] (''Juhana II'') *1563–1568 : [[Eric XIV of Sweden|Eric III]] (''Eerik XIV'') *1568–1592 : [[John III of Sweden|John II]] (restored), adopted title [[Grand Duke of Finland|Grand Prince of Finland]] (Suomen suuriruhtinas) around 1580 *1592–1599 : [[Sigismund III Vasa|Sigismund]] (''Sigismund'') (titled [[Grand Duke of Finland|Grand Prince of Finland]]) and [[John, Duke of Östergötland|John III]] (''Juhana III'') *1599-1606 : [[John, Duke of Östergötland|John III]] (''Juhana III'') *1606–1632 : [[Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden|Gustav II Adolph the Great]] (''Kustaa II Aadolf''), also titled Grand Prince of Finland *1632–1654 : [[Christina of Sweden]] (''Kristiina''), also titled Grand Princess of Finland
===The House of [[House of Pfalz-Zweibrücken|Pfalz-Zweibrücken]]===
*1654–1660 : [[Charles X Gustav of Sweden|Charles X Gustav]] (''Kaarle X Kustaa''), also titled Grand Prince of Finland *1660–1697 : [[Charles XI of Sweden|Charles XI]] (''Kaarle XI'', also titled Grand Prince of Finland *1697–1718 : [[Charles XII of Sweden|Charles XII]] (''Kaarle XII''), also titled Grand Prince of Finland *1719–1720 : [[Ulrika Eleonora of Sweden]] (''Ulriika Eleonoora''), also titled Grand Princess of Finland
===The House of [[House of Hesse|Hesse]]=== *1720–1751 : [[Frederick I of Sweden]] (''Fredrik I''), also titled Grand Prince of Finland
===The House of [[House of Holstein-Gottorp (In Sweden)|Holstein-Gottorp]]=== [[File:Gustav III of Sweden 1.jpg|thumb|100px|Kustaa III]] *1751–1771 : [[Adolf Frederick of Sweden|Adolph Frederick]] (''Aadolf Fredrik''), Grand Prince of Finland *1771–1792 : [[Gustav III of Sweden|Gustav III]] (''Kustaa III''), Grand Prince of Finland **1792–1796 : [[Charles XIII of Sweden|Charles, duke of Södermanland]] as Regent (''Södermanlannin herttua Kaarle'') *1792–1809 : [[Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden|Gustav IV Adolph]] (''Kustaa IV Aadolf''), Grand Prince of Finland
==Grand Principality of Finland in Russian Empire 1809–1917==
''The [[Grand Principality of Finland]] in the Russian Empire (1809–1917) with the Emperor of Russia as the Grand Prince of Finland (Suomen suuriruhtinas).''
===The House of [[Romanov]]=== [[File:Nicholas II of Russia painted by Earnest Lipgart.jpg|thumb|100px|Nikolai II]] *1809–1825 : [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] (''Aleksanteri I'') *1825–1855 : [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]] (''Nikolai I'') *1855–1881 : [[Alexander II of Russia|Alexander II]] (''Aleksanteri II'') *1881–1894 : [[Alexander III of Russia|Alexander III]] (''Aleksanteri III'') *1894–1917 : [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]] (''Nikolai II'')
==Interim period 1917–19==
''During the interregnum from the fall of Nicholas II to the end of the Finnish Civil War in spring 1918, sovereignty in Finland was exercised by the Finnish Parliament and, until the October Revolution and the declaration of independence, the Russian interim government. After the civil war, regents (valtionhoitaja) were appointed by the parliament and a new king elected.''
===Regents appointed by parliament=== * 27 May 1918 – 12 December 1918 : [[Pehr Evind Svinhufvud]]<ref>During Svinhufvud's regency, [[Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse]] was elected as the King of Finland on 9 October 1918. He never took office and renounced the throne on 14 December 1918.</ref> * 12 December 1918 – 26 July 1919 : [[Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim]] ===The House of [[House of Hesse|Hesse]]=== * 9 October 1918 – 14 December 1918 : [[Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse|Frederik ''Kaarle I'']], [[Kingdom of Finland (1918)|King of Finland]] (elected but never reigned)
''For later heads of state after the proclamation of the republic, see [[List of Presidents of Finland]].''
==See also== * [[Monarchy of Finland]] * [[President of Finland]] * [[Prime Minister of Finland]] * [[Governors-General of Sweden]] * [[List of Russian rulers]] * [[Governor-General of Finland]] * [[Duke of Finland]] * [[Kings of Kvenland]] * [[List of Danish monarchs]] * [[List of Swedish monarchs]] * [[List of Norwegian monarchs]] * [[List of Greenlandic rulers]] * [[List of rulers of Iceland]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Finnish Monarchs}} [[Category:Lists of monarchs|Finland]] [[Category:Finnish monarchy|*]]

page.title: List of Rajput clans of Uttar Pradesh

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Rajput clans of Uttar Pradesh'''. A [[clan]] is a group of [[people]] united by actual or perceived [[kinship]] and [[Ancestry|descent]]. Even if lineage details are unknown, clan members may be organized around a founding member or [[apical ancestor]]. The kinship-based bonds may be symbolic, whereby the clan shares a "stipulated" common ancestor that is a symbol of the clan's unity. When this "ancestor" is non-human, it is referred to as a [[totem]], which is frequently an animal.
[[Rajput]] (from [[Sanskrit]] ''raja-putra'', "son of a king"<ref name=EB />) is a member of the [[patrilineal]] clans of the [[Indian subcontinent]].{{dubious|reason=this is just one opinion, eg: there are others not yet in our Rajput article but mentioned on the talk page there|date=September 2016}} They rose to prominence from the late 6th century CE, and, until the 20th century, the Rajput rulers dominated many regions of central and [[North India|northern India]], including the eastern regions of present-day Pakistan.
==Rajput clans of Uttar Pradesh== *[[Gaur Rajput|Amethiya]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=WiAnDwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA46&ots=Stk5akIvFM&dq=amethia%20rajput&pg=PA46#v=onepage&q=amethia%20rajput&f=false|title=On the Original Inhabitants of Bharatavarsa or India|last=Oppert|first=Gustav Salomon|date=2017-06-08|publisher=BoD – Books on Demand|isbn=9789925082193|language=en}}</ref> *[[rajput clans|Badgujar]] *[[Dhakre]]<ref>People of India Uttar Pradesh Volume XLII Part One edited by A Hasan & J C Das pages 420 to 425 Manohar Publications</ref> * [[Rana (name)|Rana]] *[[Somavanshi]] * [[Bais Rajput|Bais]]<ref>{{cite book |title=Rulers, Townsmen and Bazaars: North Indian Society in the Age of British Expansion, 1770-1870 |volume=28 |series=Cambridge South Asian Studies |first=C. A. |last=Bayly |publisher=CUP Archive |year=1988 |isbn=978-0-521-31054-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xfo3AAAAIAAJ |pages=96–100}}</ref> * [[Chandel (Rajput clan)|Chandel]] * [[Dor Rajput|Dor]] – a Rajput clan of India.<ref>{{cite book |title=Medieval India: From Sultanat to the Mughals-Delhi Sultanat (1206-1526) |volume=1 |first=Satish |last=Chandra |publisher=Har-Anand Publications |year=2004 |isbn=978-8-12411-064-5 |page=27 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L5eFzeyjBTQC&pg=PA27}}</ref> * [[Jadaun]] – a clan ([[gotra]]) of Rajputs.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oscmJoix2IAC&pg=PA200 |title=Islamization in Modern South Asia: Deobandi Reform and the Gujjar Response |publisher=Walter de Gruyter, |year=2012 |accessdate=30 September 2014 |first=David Emmanuel |last=Singh |page=200}}</ref> * [[Pundir]]<ref>{{cite book |title=The Peasant and the Raj: Studies in Agrarian Society and Peasant Rebellion in Colonial India |first=Eric |last=Stokes |authorlink=Eric Thomas Stokes |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1980 |isbn=978-0-52129-770-7 |page=172}}</ref> * [[Sengar]]<ref>{{cite book |title=The Peasant and the Raj: Studies in Agrarian Society and Peasant Rebellion in Colonial India |first=Eric |last=Stokes |authorlink=Eric Thomas Stokes |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1980 |isbn=978-0-52129-770-7 |page=78}}</ref> *[[Raghuvanshi]]
==See also== {{portal|India|Lists}} * [[Caste]] ** [[Caste system in India]]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=EB>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/490157/Rajput|title=Rajput|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=27 November 2010}}</ref> }}
{{Rajput clans of Uttar Pradesh}}

revision.comment: /* top */clean up, replaced: Journal of postgraduate medicine → Journal of Postgraduate Medicine
revision.text:
'''Olfactory reference syndrome''' ('''ORS''') is a [[mental disorder|psychiatric condition]] in which there is a persistent false belief and preoccupation with the idea of emitting abnormal [[body odor]]s which the patient thinks that are foul and offensive to other individuals.<ref name=Phillips2006 /><ref name=Begum2011/>
People with this condition often misinterpret others' [[Human behavior|behaviors]], e.g. [[Sniffing (behavior)|sniffing]], touching [[nose]] or opening a [[window]], as being referential to an unpleasant body odor which in reality is non-existent and can not be detected by other people.
This disorder is often accompanied by [[shame]], [[embarrassment]], significant [[Distress (medicine)|distress]], avoidance behavior, [[social phobia]] and [[social isolation]].<ref name=Lochner2003>{{cite journal|last=Lochner|first=C|author2=Stein, DJ|title=Olfactory reference syndrome: diagnostic criteria and differential diagnosis.|journal=Journal of Postgraduate Medicine|date=Oct–Dec 2003|volume=49|issue=4|pages=328–31|pmid=14699232|url=http://www.jpgmonline.com/article.asp?issn=0022-3859;year=2003;volume=49;issue=4;spage=328;epage=331;aulast=Lochner}}</ref>
The term ''olfactory reference syndrome'' comes from: * [[Olfaction|Olfactory]], pertaining to the sense of smell. * [[Reference#Psychology|Reference]], because of the belief that the behavior of others is referential to a supposed odor. * [[Syndrome]], because it is a recognizable set of features that occur together.
==Classification== Although the existence of ORS is generally accepted,<ref name=Begum2011 /><ref name=Arenas2013 /> there is some controversy as to whether it is a distinct condition or merely a part or manifestation of other psychiatric conditions, mainly due to the overlapping similarities.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> Similarly, there is controversy with regards how the disorder should be classified.<ref name=Begum2011 /><ref name=Feusner2010 /> As ORS has obsessive and compulsive features, some consider it as a type of [[obsessive–compulsive spectrum|obsessive compulsive spectrum disorder]], while others consider it an [[anxiety disorder]] due to the strong [[anxiety]] component. It is also suggested to be a type of [[body dysmorphic disorder]] or, as it involves a single [[delusion]]al belief, some suggest that ORS is a monosymptomatic hypochondriacal [[psychosis]] ([[hypochondriasis|hypochondriacal]] type of [[delusional disorder]], see [[monothematic delusion]]).<ref name=Begum2011 /><ref name=Feusner2010 />
The [[World Health Organization]]'s 10th revision of the [[International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems]] ([[ICD-10]]) does not have a specific entry for ORS,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> or use the term, but in the "persistent delusional disorders" section, states delusions can "express a conviction that others think that they smell."<ref name=Feusner2010 />
ORS has also never been allocated a dedicated entry in any edition of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]'s [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]].<ref name=Feusner2010 /> In the third edition (DSM-III), ORS was mentioned under "atypical [[somatoform disorder]]s".<ref name=Begum2011 /> The revised third edition (DSM-III-R) mentions ORS in the text, stating: "convictions that the person emits a foul odor are one of the most common types of delusion disorder, somatic type."<ref name=Feusner2010 /> The fourth edition (DSM-IV), does not use the term ORS<ref name=Feusner2010 /> but again mentions such a condition under "delusional disorder, somatic type",<ref name=Begum2011 /> stating "somatic delusions can occur in several forms. Most common are the person's conviction that he or she emits a foul odor from the skin, mouth, rectum or vagina."<ref name=Feusner2010 /> In the fifth edition (DSM-5), ORS again does not appear as a distinct diagnosis, but it is mentioned in relation to [[taijin kyōfushō]] (対人恐怖症, "disorder of fear of personal interaction").<ref name=DSM5>{{cite book|title=Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders: DSM-5.|year=2013|publisher=Amer. Psychiatric Pub. Incorporated.|location=Arlington, VA|isbn=978-0-89042-554-1|pages=263–264, 837}}</ref> The variants of taijin kyōfushō (shubo-kyofu "the phobia of a deformed body" and jikoshu-kyofu "fear of foul body odor") are listed under 300.3 (F42) "other specified obsessive compulsive and related disorders",<ref name=DSM5 /> and is about someone's fear that his or her body, or its functions, is offensive to other people.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> There are four subtypes of taijin kyōfushō.<ref name=Sajatovic /> 17% of these individuals suffer from "the phobia of having foul body odor", the subtype termed jikoshu-kyofu.<ref name=Feusner2010 /><ref name=Sajatovic>{{cite book|veditors=Sajatovic M, Loue S|title=Encyclopedia of immigrant health|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4419-5659-0}}</ref> Although taijin kyōfushō has been described as a [[culture-bound syndrome]] confined to east Asia (e.g. Japan and Korea),<ref name=Lochner2003 /><ref name=Feusner2010 /> it has been suggested that the jikoshu-kyofu variant of taijin kyōfushō is closely related or identical to ORS,<ref name=Lochner2003 /><ref name=Arenas2013 /> and that such a condition occurs in other cultures.<ref name=DSM5 /> However, some Western sources state that jikoshu-kyofu and ORS are distinguishable because of cultural differences, i.e. Western culture being primarily concerned with individual needs, and Japanese culture primarily with the needs of the many. Hence, it is claimed that ORS mainly focuses on the affected individual's embarrassment, and jikoshu-kyofu is focused on the fear of creating embarrassment in others. In this article, jikoshu-kyofu and ORS are considered as one condition.
Synonyms for ORS, many historical, include bromidrosiphobia,<ref name=Begum2011 /> olfactory phobic syndrome,<ref name=Begum2011 /> chronic olfactory paranoid syndrome,<ref name=Begum2011 /> autodysomophobia,<ref name=Begum2011 /> delusions of bromosis,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> hallucinations of smell<ref name=Feusner2010 /> and olfactory delusional syndrome.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} By definition, the many terms which have been suggested in the dental literature to refer to subjective halitosis complaints (i.e. where a person complains of halitosis yet no odor is detectable clinically) can also be considered under the umbrella of ORS. Examples include halitophobia,<ref name=Sterer2011 /> non-genuine halitosis, delusional halitosis,<ref name=Sterer2011 /> pseudo-halitosis, imaginary halitosis,<ref name=Phillips2007 /> psychosomatic halitosis, and self halitosis.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
==Signs and symptoms== The onset of ORS may be sudden, where it usually follows after a precipitating event, or gradual.<ref name=Phillips2006 />
===Odor complaint=== The defining feature of ORS is excessive thoughts of having offensive body odor(s) which are detectable to others. The individual may report that the odor comes from: the nose and/or mouth, i.e. [[halitosis]] (bad breath), the anus, the genitals, the skin generally, or specifically the groin, armpits or feet. The source(s) of the supposed odor may also change over time.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> There are also some who are unsure of the exact origin of the odor.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> The odor is typically reported to be continuously present.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> The character of the odor may be reported as similar to bodily substances, e.g. [[feces]], [[flatus]], [[urine]], [[sweat]], [[vomitus]], [[semen]], [[vaginal secretion]]s; or alternatively it may be an unnatural, non-human or chemical odor, e.g. [[ammonia]],<ref name=Feusner2010 /> [[detergent]],<ref name=Feusner2010 /> rotten [[onion]]s,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> burnt rags,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> candles,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> garbage,<ref name=Begum2011 /> burning fish,<ref name=Begum2011 /> medicines,<ref name=Begum2011 /> old cheese.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Again, the reported character of the odor complaint may change over time.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Halitosis appears to be the most common manifestation of ORS,<ref name=Richter1995 /> with 75% complaining of bad breath, alone or in combination with other odors.<ref name=Phillips2011 /> The next most common complaint was sweat (60%).<ref name=Phillips2011>{{cite journal|last=Phillips|first=KA|author2=Menard, W|title=Olfactory reference syndrome: demographic and clinical features of imagined body odor.|journal=General hospital psychiatry|date=Jul–Aug 2011|volume=33|issue=4|pages=398–406|pmid=21762838|pmc=3139109|doi=10.1016/j.genhosppsych.2011.04.004}}</ref>
Although all individuals with ORS believe they have an odor, in some cases the individual reports they cannot perceive the odor themselves. In the latter cases, the belief arises via misinterpretation of the behavior of others or with the rationale that a disorder of smell which prevents self detection of the odor (i.e. [[anosmia]]) exists. In the cases where the non-existent odor can be detected, this is usually considered as [[phantosmia]] ([[olfactory hallucination]]). Olfactory hallucination can be considered the result of the belief in an odor delusion, or the belief a result of the olfactory hallucination.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> In one review, the individual with ORS was unreservedly convinced that he or she could detect the odor themselves in 22% of cases, whilst in 19% there was occasional or intermittent detection and in 59% lack of self-detection was present.<ref name=Begum2011 />
Some distinguish ''delusional'' and ''non-delusional'' forms of ORS. In the delusional type, there is complete conviction that the odor is real. In the non-delusional type, the individual is capable of some [[Insight#Psychiatry|insight]] into the condition, and can recognize that the odor might not be real, and that their level of concern is excessive.<ref name=Feusner2010 /> Others argue that reported cases of ORS present a spectrum of different levels of insight.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Since sometimes the core belief of ORS is not of delusional intensity, it is argued that considering the condition as a form of delusional disorder, as seems to occur in the DSM, is inappropriate.<ref name=Begum2011 /> In one review, in 57% of cases the beliefs were fixed, held with complete conviction, and the individual could not be reassured that the odor was non existent. In 43% of cases the individual held the beliefs with less than complete conviction, and was able to varying degrees to consider the possibility that the odor was not existent.<ref name=Begum2011 />
Other symptoms may be reported and are claimed to be related to the cause of the odor, such as malfunction of the anal sphincter, a skin disease, "diseased womb", stomach problems or other unknown [[organic disease]].<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Excessive washing in ORS has been reported to cause the development of [[eczema]].<ref name=Phillips2006 />
===Referential ideas=== People with ORS misinterpret the behavior of others to be related to the imagined odor ([[Ideas of reference and delusions of reference|thoughts of reference]]). In one review, ideas of reference were present in 74% of cases.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Usually, these involve misinterpretations of comments, gestures and actions of other people such that it is believed that an offensive smell from the individual is being referred to.<ref name=Begum2011 /> These thoughts of reference are more pronounced in social situations which the individual with ORS may find stressful, such as public transport, crowded lift, workplace, classroom, etc.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Example behaviors which are misinterpreted include coughing, sneezing, turning of the head, opening a window, facial expressions, sniffing, touching nose, scratching head, gestures, moving away, avoiding the person, whistling.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Commonly, when being in proximity to others who are talking among themselves, persons with ORS will be convinced that the conversation is about his or her odor. Even the actions of animals (e.g. barking of dogs) can be interpreted as referential to an odor.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Persons with ORS may have trouble concentrating at a given task or in particular situations due to obsessive thoughts concerning body odor.
===Repetitive behavior=== 95% of persons with ORS engage in at least one excessive hygiene, grooming or other related repetitive practice in an attempt to alleviate, mask and monitor the perceived odor.<ref name=Phillips2007 /><ref name=Feusner2009 /> This has been described as a contrite reaction,<ref name=Begum2011 /> and repetitive, counterphobic, "safety", ritual or compulsive behaviors.<ref name=Phillips2006 /><ref name=Phillips2007>{{cite journal|vauthors=Phillips KA, Castle DJ|title=How to help patients with olfactory reference syndrome|journal=Current Psychiatry|year=2007|volume=6|issue=3|url=http://www.currentpsychiatry.com/fileadmin/cp_archive/pdf/0603/0603CP_Article3.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511152747/http://www.currentpsychiatry.com/fileadmin/cp_archive/pdf/0603/0603CP_Article3.pdf|archivedate=2015-05-11|df=}}</ref> Despite these measures, the odor symptom is reported to still offend other people.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Example ORS behaviors include: repetitive [[showering]] and other [[Personal grooming|grooming]] behaviors,<ref name=Feusner2009>{{cite journal|last=Feusner|first=JD|author2=Hembacher, E |author3=Phillips, KA |title=The mouse who couldn't stop washing: pathologic grooming in animals and humans.|journal=CNS spectrums|date=Sep 2009|volume=14|issue=9|pages=503–13|pmid=19890232|pmc=2853748}}</ref> excessive tooth brushing,<ref name=Feusner2009 /> or tongue scraping (a treatment for halitosis), repeated smelling of oneself to check for any odor,<ref name=Feusner2010>{{cite journal|last=Feusner|first=JD|author2=Phillips, KA |author3=Stein, DJ |title=Olfactory reference syndrome: issues for DSM-V.|journal=Depression and Anxiety|date=Jun 2010|volume=27|issue=6|pages=592–9|pmid=20533369|url=http://www.dsm5.org/Research/Documents/Feusner_ORS.pdf|doi=10.1002/da.20688|pmc=4247225}}</ref> over-frequent bathroom use,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> attempts to mask the odor,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> with excessive use of [[deodorant]]s, [[perfume]]s, [[mouthwash]], mint, chewing gum, scented candles, and soap;<ref name=Phillips2006 /> changing clothes (e.g. underwear),<ref name=Arenas2013>{{cite journal|last=Arenas|first=B|author2=Garcia, G |author3=Gómez, J |author4=Renovell, M |author5=García, V |author6=Olucha-Bordonau, FE |author7= Sanjuán, J |title=[Olfactory reference syndrome: a systematic review].|journal=Revista de neurologia|date=Jan 16, 2013|volume=56|issue=2|pages=65–71|pmid=23307351|url=http://www.revneurol.com/sec/resumen.php?or=pubmed&id=2012555#}}</ref> multiple times per day,<ref name=Begum2011 /> frequent washing of clothes, wearing several layers of clothing, wrapping feet in plastic,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> wearing garments marketed as odor-reducing,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> eating special diets, dietary supplements (e.g. intended to reduce flatulence odor),<ref name=Phillips2006 /><ref name=Arenas2013 /> repeatedly seeking reassurance from others that there is no odor, although the negative response is usually interpreted instead as politeness rather than truth,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> and avoidance behaviors such habitually sitting at a distance from others, minimizing movement in an attempt "not to spread the odor", keeping the mouth closed and avoiding talking or talking with a hand in front of the mouth.<ref name=Phillips2006 />
===Functional impairment=== Persons with ORS tend to develop a behavior pattern of avoidance of social activities and progressive social withdrawal. They often avoid travel, dating, relationships, break off engagements and avoid family activities.<ref name=Phillips2007 /> Due to shame and embarrassment, they may avoid school or work, or repeatedly change jobs and move to another town.<ref name=Phillips2007 /> Significant developments may occur such as loss of employment,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[divorce]], becoming housebound, psychiatric hospitalization, and suicide attempts.<ref name=Phillips2007 /> According to some reports, 74% of persons with ORS avoid social situations,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> 47% avoid work, academic or other important activities,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> 40% had been housebound for at least once week because of ORS,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> and 31.6% had experienced psychiatric hospitalization.<ref name=Feusner2010 /> With regards suicide, reports range from 43-68% with suicidal ideation, and 32% with a history of at least one suicide attempt. 5.6% died by suicide.<ref name=Feusner2010 /><ref name=Phillips2007 />
===Psychiatric co-morbidity=== Psychiatric [[co-morbidity]] in ORS is reported. Depression, which is often severe, may be a result of ORS, or may be pre-existing.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> [[Personality disorder]]s, especially [[cluster C]], and predominantly the [[avoidant personality disorder|avoidant type]], may exist with ORS.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[Bipolar disorder]], schizophrenia, hypochondriasis, alcohol or drug abuse and obsessive compulsive disorder may also be co-morbid with ORS.<ref name=Phillips2006 />
==Causes== The causes of ORS are unknown.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> It is thought that significant negative experiences may trigger the development of ORS. These have been considered as two types: key traumatic experiences related to smell, and life [[stressor]]s present when the condition developed but which were unrelated to smell.<ref name=Begum2011 /> In one review, 85% of reported cases had traumatic, smell-related experiences, and 17% of cases had stress factors unrelated to smell.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Reported smell-related experiences usually revolve around family members, friends, co-workers, peers or other people making comments about an odor from the person, which causes embarrassment and shame.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Examples include accusation of flatulence during a religious ceremony,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> or being [[bullying|bullied]] for flatulence such at school,<ref name=Begum2011 /> accidental urination in class,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> announcements about a passenger needing to use deodorant over speaker by a driver on public transport,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[sinusitis]] which caused a bad taste in the mouth,<ref name=Begum2011 /> mockery about a fish odor from a finger which had been inserted into the person's vagina in the context of a sexual assault,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> and revulsion about [[menarche]] and brother's sexual intimacy.<ref name=Begum2011 /> It has been suggested that a proportion of such reported experiences may not have been real, but rather early symptom of ORS (i.e. referential thoughts).<ref name=Sterer2011 /> Examples of non smell-related stressful periods include guilt due to a romantic affair,<ref name=Begum2011 /> being left by a partner,<ref name=Begum2011 /> violence in school,<ref name=Begum2011 /> family illness when growing up (e.g. cancer),<ref name=Begum2011 /> and bullying.<ref name=Begum2011 />
The importance of a [[Family history (medicine)|family history]] of mental illness or other conditions in ORS is unclear,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> because most reported cases have lacked this information.<ref name=Begum2011 /> In some cases, there has been reported psychiatric and medical conditions in [[first degree relative]]s such as schizophrenia,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> psychosis,<ref name=Begum2011 /> alcoholism,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> suicide,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> affective disorders,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> obsessive compulsive disorder,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> anxiety,<ref name=Begum2011 /> paranoia,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> neurosis,<ref name=Begum2011 /> sociopathy,<ref name=Begum2011 /> and [[epilepsy]].<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Sometimes more than one family member had a noteworthy condition.<ref name=Begum2011 />
[[Neuroimaging]] has been used to investigate ORS. [[Hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime]] [[single-photon emission computed tomography]] (HMPAO SPECT) demonstrated hypoperfusion of the [[frontotemporal lobe]] in one case.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> That is to say, part of the brain was receiving insufficient blood flow. In another, [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]] was carried out while the person with ORS listened to both neutral words and emotive words. Compared to an age and sex matched healthy control subject under the same conditions, the individual with ORS showed more activation areas in the brain when listening to emotionally loaded words. This difference was described as abnormal, but less pronounced as would be observed in the brain of a person with a psychotic disorder.<ref name=Arenas2013 />
==Diagnosis==
===Diagnostic criteria=== [[Diagnostic criteria#Diagnostic criteria|Diagnostic criteria]] have been proposed for ORS:<ref name=Begum2011 /><ref name=Arenas2013 /><ref name=Sterer2011>{{cite book|author1=Nir Sterer |author2=Mel Rosenberg |title=Breath odors origin, diagnosis, and management|year=2011|publisher=Springer|location=Berlin|isbn=978-3-642-19312-5|pages=89–90|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P_89d-5gzjUC&pg=PA89&dq=%22olfactory+reference+syndrome%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=LfjSUo7TN4bCyQOE5YBg&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22olfactory%20reference%20syndrome%22&f=false}}</ref>
* Persistent (> six months), false belief that one emits an offensive odor, which is not perceived by others. There may be degrees of insight (i.e. the belief may or may not be of delusional intensity). * This pre-occupation causes clinically significant distress (depression, anxiety, shame), social and occupational disability, or may be time-consuming (i.e. preoccupies the individual at least one hour per day). * The belief is not a symptom of schizophrenia or other psychotic disorder, and not due to the effects of medication or recreational drug abuse, or any other general medical condition.
===Differential diagnosis===
The [[differential diagnosis]] for ORS may be complicated as the disorder shares features with other conditions. Consequently, ORS may be [[misdiagnosis|misdiagnosed]] as another medical or psychiatric condition and ''[[vice versa]]''.
The typical history of ORS involves a long delay while the person continues to believe there is a genuine odor. On average, a patient with ORS goes undiagnosed for about eight years.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> Repeated consultation with multiple different non-psychiatric medical specialists ("[[doctor shopping]]") in an attempt to have their non-existent body odor treated is frequently reported.<ref name=Begum2011 /> Individuals with ORS may present to [[dermatology|dermatologists]],<ref name=Robles2008>{{cite journal|last=Robles|first=DT|author2=Romm, S |author3=Combs, H |author4=Olson, J |author5= Kirby, P |title=Delusional disorders in dermatology: a brief review.|journal=Dermatology online journal|date=Jun 15, 2008|volume=14|issue=6|pages=2|pmid=18713583}}</ref> [[gastroenterology|gastroentrologists]],<ref name=Phillips2006>{{cite book|vauthors=Phillips KA, Gunderson C, Gruber U, Castle D|chapter=Delusions of body malodour: the olfactory reference syndrome.|veditors=Brewer WJ, Castle D, Pantelis C|title=Olfaction and the brain|date=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-0-521-84922-7|pages=334–353|url=http://elib.fk.uwks.ac.id/asset/archieve/e-book/ILMU%20PENYAKIT%20SARAF%20-%20NEUROLOGI%20-%20NEUROLOGY/Olfaction%20and%20the%20Brain.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108230325/http://elib.fk.uwks.ac.id/asset/archieve/e-book/ILMU%20PENYAKIT%20SARAF%20-%20NEUROLOGI%20-%20NEUROLOGY/Olfaction%20and%20the%20Brain.pdf|archivedate=2014-01-08|df=}}</ref> [[otolaryngology|otolaryngologists]],<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[dentistry|dentists]],<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[proctology|proctologists]],<ref name=Phillips2007 /> and [[gynecology|gynecologists]]. Despite the absence of any clinically detectable odor, physicians and surgeons may embark on unnecessary investigations (e.g. [[gastroscopy]]),<ref name=Sterer2011 /> and treatments, including surgery such as [[thoracic sympathectomy]], [[tonsillectomy]], etc. Such treatments generally have no long-term effect on the individual's belief in an odor symptom.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> If non-psychiatric clinicians refuse to carry out treatment on the basis that there is no real odor and offer to refer them to a psychologist or psychiatrist, persons with ORS typically refuse and instead seek "a better" doctor/dentist.<ref name=Phillips2006 /><ref name=Newman2012 />
Conversely, some have suggested that medical conditions which cause genuine odor may sometimes be misdiagnosed as ORS.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wise|first=PM|author2=Eades, J |author3=Tjoa, S |author4=Fennessey, PV |author5= Preti, G |title=Individuals reporting idiopathic malodor production: demographics and incidence of trimethylaminuria.|journal=The American Journal of Medicine|date=Nov 2011|volume=124|issue=11|pages=1058–63|pmid=21851918 |doi=10.1016/j.amjmed.2011.05.030}}</ref> There are a great many different medical conditions which are reported to potentially cause a genuine odor, and these are usually considered according to the origin of the odor, e.g. [[halitosis]] (bad breath), [[bromhidrosis]] (body odor), etc.<ref name=brent>{{cite book|last=Brent|first=A|title=Textbook of pediatric emergency medicine|year=2010|publisher=Wolters Kluwer/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins Health|location=Philadelphia|isbn=1-60547-159-3|edition=6th|editors=Gary R. Fleisher, Stephen Ludwig ; associate editors, Richard G. Bachur ... [et. al]|chapter=Chapter 46, Odor - unusual}}</ref><ref name=shirasu2011>{{cite journal|last=Shirasu|first=M|author2=Touhara, K|title=The scent of disease: volatile organic compounds of the human body related to disease and disorder.|journal=Journal of Biochemistry|date=Sep 2011|volume=150|issue=3|pages=257–66|pmid=21771869|doi=10.1093/jb/mvr090}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Stitt|first=WZ|author2=Goldsmith, A|title=Scratch and sniff. The dynamic duo.|journal=Archives of Dermatology|date=Sep 1995|volume=131|issue=9|pages=997–9|pmid=7661625|doi=10.1001/archderm.131.9.997}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Pausch|first=NC|author2=Reiss, M |author3=Reiss, G |title=[Malodor from the nose. Causes, diagnosis and therapy].|journal=[[Medizinische Monatsschrift für Pharmazeuten]]|date=Feb 2001|volume=24|issue=2|pages=48–50|pmid=11255985}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Reiss|first=M|author2=Reiss, G|title=[Nasal odors].|journal=Praxis|date=Nov 23, 2000|volume=89|issue=47|pages=1953–5|pmid=11143967}}</ref><ref name="Sobel2012">{{cite journal|last=Sobel|first=JD|title=Genital malodour in women: an unmet therapeutic challenge.|journal=Sexually transmitted infections|date=Jun 2012|volume=88|issue=4|pages=238|pmid=22383853|doi=10.1136/sextrans-2011-050440}}</ref><ref name="Subramanian2012">{{cite journal|last=Subramanian|first=C|author2=Nyirjesy, P |author3=Sobel, JD |title=Genital malodor in women: a modern reappraisal.|journal=Journal of lower genital tract disease|date=Jan 2012|volume=16|issue=1|pages=49–55|pmid=21964208|doi=10.1097/LGT.0b013e31822b7512}}</ref> These conditions are excluded before a diagnosis of ORS is made.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> Although there are a multitude of different publications on topics like halitosis, the symptom is still poorly understood and managed in practice.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Coil|first=JM|author2=Yaegaki, K |author3=Matsuo, T |author4= Miyazaki, H |title=Treatment needs (TN) and practical remedies for halitosis.|journal=International dental journal|date=Jun 2002|volume=52 Suppl 3|pages=187–91|pmid=12090450}}</ref> It is recognized that symptoms such as halitosis can be intermittent, and therefore may not be present at the time of the consultation, leading to misdiagnosis.<ref name=Richter1995>{{cite journal|last=Richter|first=JL|title=Diagnosis and treatment of halitosis.|journal=Compendium of continuing education in dentistry (Jamesburg, N.J. : 1995)|date=Apr 1996|volume=17|issue=4|pages=370–2, 374–6 passim; quiz 388|pmid=9051972}}</ref> Individuals with genuine odor symptoms may present with similar mindset and behavior to persons with ORS. For example, one otolaryngologist researcher noted "behavioral problems such as continuous occupation with oral hygiene issues, obsessive use of cosmetic breath freshening products such as mouthwashes, candies, chewing gums, and sprays, avoiding close contact with other people, and turning the head away during conversation" as part of what was termed ''"[[skunk]] syndrome"'' in patients with genuine halitosis secondary to chronic [[tonsillitis]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Finkelstein|first=Y|author2=Talmi, YP |author3=Ophir, D |author4= Berger, G |title=Laser cryptolysis for the treatment of halitosis.|journal=Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery|date=Oct 2004|volume=131|issue=4|pages=372–7|doi=10.1016/j.otohns.2004.02.044|pmid=15467602}}</ref> Another author, writing about halitosis, noted that there are generally three types of persons that complain of halitosis: those with above average odor, those with average or near-average odor who are oversensitive, and those with below average or no odor who believe they have offensive breath. Therefore, in persons with genuine odor complaints, the distress and concern may typically be out of proportion to the reality of the problem.<ref name=Richter1995 /> Genuine halitosis has been described as a social barrier between the individual and friends, relatives, partners and colleagues, and may negatively alter self-esteem and quality of life.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Elias|first=MS|author2=Ferriani, Md|title=Historical and social aspects of halitosis.|journal=Revista latino-americana de enfermagem|date=Sep–Oct 2006|volume=14|issue=5|pages=821–3|pmid=17117270|doi=10.1590/s0104-11692006000500026}}</ref> Similar psychosocial problems are reported in other conditions which cause genuine odor symptoms.<ref name=Mountain2008>{{cite journal|last=Mountain|first=H|author2=Brisbane, JM |author3=Hooper, AJ |author4=Burnett, JR |author5= Goldblatt, J |title=Trimethylaminuria (fish malodour syndrome): a "benign" genetic condition with major psychosocial sequelae.|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=Oct 20, 2008|volume=189|issue=8|pages=468|pmid=18928446}}</ref><ref name=Scarff2009>{{cite journal|last=Scarff|first=CE|title=Sweaty, smelly hands and feet.|journal=Australian family physician|date=Sep 2009|volume=38|issue=9|pages=666–9|pmid=19893792|url=http://www.racgp.org.au/afpbackissues/2009/200909/200909scarff.pdf}}</ref> In the literature on halitosis, emphasis is frequently placed on multiple consultations to reduce the risk of misdiagnosis, and also asking the individual to have a reliable confidant accompany them to the consultation who can confirm the reality of the reported symptom. ORS patients are unable to provide such confidants as they have no objective odor.<ref name=Richter1995 /><ref name=Newman2012>{{cite book|last=(editors) Newman MG, Takei HH, Klokkevold PR, Carranza FA|title=Carranza's clinical periodontology|year=2012|publisher=Elsevier/Saunders|location=St. Louis, Mo.|isbn=978-1-4377-0416-7|pages=1333, 1334|edition=11th}}</ref>
Various organic diseases may cause parosmias (distortion of the sense of smell). Also, since smell and taste are intimately linked senses, disorders of gustation (e.g. [[dysgeusia]]- taste dysfunction) can present as a complaint related to smell, and ''vice versa''. These conditions, collectively termed chemosensory dysfunctions, are many and varied, and they may trigger a person to complain of an odor than is not present,<ref name="Falcão2012">{{cite journal|last=Falcão|first=DP|author2=Vieira, CN|author3=Batista de Amorim, RF|title=Breaking paradigms: a new definition for halitosis in the context of pseudo-halitosis and halitophobia.|journal=Journal of breath research|date=Mar 2012|volume=6|issue=1|pages=017105|pmid=22368258|doi=10.1088/1752-7155/6/1/017105}}</ref> however the diagnostic criteria for ORS require the exclusion of any such causes.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> They include pathology of the right hemisphere of the brain,<ref name=Lochner2003 /> [[substance abuse]],<ref name=Arenas2013 /> arteriovenous malformations in the brain,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> and temporal lobe epilepsy.<ref name=Arenas2013 />
[[Social anxiety disorder]] (SAD) and ORS have some demographic and clinical similarities.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> Where the social anxiety and avoidance behavior is primarily focussed on concern about body odors, ORS is a more appropriate diagnosis than [[avoidant personality disorder]] or SAD.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> Body dismorphic disorder (BDD) has been described as the closest diagnosis in DSM-IV to ORS as both primarily focus on bodily symptoms.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> The defining difference between the two is that in BDD the preoccupation is with physical appearance not body odors.<ref name=Lochner2003 /> Similarly, where obsessive behaviors are directly and consistently related to body odors rather than anything else, ORS is a more appropriate diagnosis than obsessive compulsive disorder, in which obsessions are different and multiple over time.<ref name=Lochner2003 />
ORS may be misdiagnosed as schizophrenia.<ref name=Begum2011 /><ref name=Feusner2010 /> About 13% of schizophrenics have olfactory hallucinations.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> Generally, schizophrenic hallucinations are perceived as having an imposed, external origin, while in ORS they are recognized as originating from the individual.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> The suggested diagnostic criteria mean that the possibility of ORS is negated by a diagnosis of schizophrenia in which persistent delusions of an offensive body odor and olfactory hallucinations are contributing features for [[Diagnosis of schizophrenia#Criteria|criterion A]].<ref name=Phillips2011 /> However, some reported ORS cases were presented as co-morbid.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Indeed, some have suggested that ORS may in time transform into schizophrenia, but others state there is little evidence for this.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Persons with ORS have none of the other criteria to qualify for a diagnosis of schizophrenia.<ref name=Lochner2003 />
It has been suggested that various special investigations may be indicated to help rule out some of the above conditions. Depending upon the case, this might include neuroimaging, thyroid and adrenal hormone tests, and analysis of body fluids (e.g. blood) with [[gas chromatography]].<ref name=Lochner2003 />
==Treatment==<!-- historic [[Electroconvulsive therapy]] [[lobotomy]] --> There is no agreed treatment protocol.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> In most reported cases of ORS the attempted treatment was [[antidepressant]]s, followed by [[antipsychotic]]s and various [[Psychotherapy|psychotherapies]].<ref name=Arenas2013 /> Little data are available regarding the efficacy of these treatments in ORS, but some suggest that psychotherapy yields the highest rate of response to treatment, and that antidepressants are more efficacious than antipsychotics (response rates 78%, 55% and 33% respectively).<ref name=Phillips2006 /> According to one review, 43% of cases which showed overall improvement required more than one treatment approach, and in only 31% did the first administered treatment lead to some improvement.<ref name=Arenas2013 />
Pharmacotherapies that have been used for ORS include [[antidepressant]]s,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> (e.g. [[selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor]]s, [[tricyclic antidepressant]]s, [[monoamine oxidase inhibitor]]s), [[antipsychotic]]s, (e.g. [[blonanserin]],<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[lithium (medication)|lithium]],<ref name=Arenas2013 /> [[chlorpromazine]]),<ref name=Richter1995 /> and [[benzodiazepine]]s.<ref name=Arenas2013 /> The most common treatment used for ORS is SSRIs. Specific antidepressants that have been used include [[clomipramine]].<ref name=Lochner2003 />
Psychotherapies that have been used for ORS include [[cognitive behavioral therapy]], [[eye movement desensitization and reprocessing]].<ref name=Lochner2003 />
==Prognosis== When untreated, the prognosis for ORS is generally poor. It is chronic, lasting many years or even decades with worsening of symptoms rather than spontaneous remission.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> Transformation to another psychiatric condition is unlikely, although very rarely what appears to be ORS may later manifest into schizophrenia,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> psychosis,<ref name=Begum2011 /> mania,<ref name=Begum2011 /> or major depressive disorder.<ref name=Begum2011 /> The most significant risk is suicide.
When treated, the prognosis is better. In one review, the proportion of treated ORS cases which reported various outcomes were assessed. On average, the patients were followed for 21 months (range: two weeks to ten years). With treatment, 30% recovered (i.e. no longer experienced ORS odor beliefs and thoughts of reference), 37% improved and in 33% there was a deterioration in the condition (including suicide) or no change from the pre-treatment status.<ref name=Begum2011 />
==Epidemiology== Cases have been reported from many different countries around the world. It is difficult to estimate the [[prevalence]] of ORS in the general population because data are limited and unreliable,<ref name=Arenas2013 /> and due to the delusional nature of the condition and the characteristic secrecy and shame.<ref name=Phillips2006 />
For unknown reasons, males appear to be affected twice as commonly as females.<ref name=Phillips2006 /> High proportions of ORS patients are unemployed, single,<ref name=Phillips2006 /> and not socially active.<ref name=Sterer2011 /> The average age reported is around 20–21 years,<ref name=Begum2011 /><ref name=Phillips2007 /> with almost 60% of cases occurring in subjects under 20 in one report,<ref name=Begum2011 /> although another review reported an older average age for both males (29) and females (40).<ref name=Arenas2013 />
==History, society and culture== The term ''olfactory reference syndrome'' was first proposed in 1971 by William Pryse-Phillips.<ref name=Munro>{{cite book|last=Munro|first=Alistair|title=Delusional Disorder: Paranoia and Related Illnesses. Concepts in clinical psychiatry|year=1999|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-42732-6|pages=79, 91, 92|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tjZRqzXK2gkC&pg=PA92&dq=%22olfactory+reference+syndrome%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=x8TMUoX7DOGuyAP4s4G4CQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22olfactory%20reference%20syndrome%22&f=false}}</ref> Prior to this, published descriptions of what is now thought to be ORS appear from the late 1800s,<ref name=Feusner2010 /> with the first being Potts 1891.<ref name=Begum2011>{{cite journal|last=Begum|first=M|author2=McKenna, PJ|title=Olfactory reference syndrome: a systematic review of the world literature.|journal=Psychological Medicine|date=Mar 2011|volume=41|issue=3|pages=453–61|pmid=20529415|doi=10.1017/S0033291710001091}}</ref> Often the condition was incorrectly described as other conditions, e.g. schizophrenia.<ref name=Feusner2010 />
In modern times, commercial advertising pressures have altered the public's attitude towards problems such as halitosis,<ref name=Richter1995 /> which have taken on greater negative psychosocial [[sequela]]e as a result. For example, in the United States, a poll reported that 55–75 million citizens consider bad breath a "principal concern" during social encounters.<ref name=Richter1995 />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/podcasts/insights-olfactory-reference-syndrome "Insights on Olfactory Reference Syndrome" by Prof. K Phillips August 12, 2010 (Podcast, free membership required to access)] * [http://www.mghocd.org/ors/ Olfactory reference syndrome, OCD and Related Disorders Clinic and Research Unit at Massachusetts General Hospital] * [http://www.ocdla.com/olfactoryreferencesyndrome.html Olfactory reference syndrome, OCD Center of Los Angeles]

'''Prostitution in Armenia''' is illegal<ref name="stats">{{cite web|url=https://news.am/eng/news/125553.html|title=Prostitution statistics in Armenia|publisher=|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref> under [[administrative law]]<ref name="ency">{{cite book|last1=Ditmore|first1=Melissa Hope |title=Encyclopedia of prostitution and sex work|date=2006|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn.|isbn=978-0313329685|page=90}}</ref> (Article 179.1).<ref>{{cite web|title=Republic of Armenia Law Enforcement Anti-Trafficking Training Needs Assessment|url=http://www.osce.org/yerevan/30894?download=true|website=[[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]]|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=December 2007}}</ref> Related activities such as running a [[brothel]] and [[pimping]] are prohibited by the Criminal Code,<ref name="chartsbin">{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=ChartsBin|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="criminal">{{cite web|title=Criminal Code of the Republic of Armenia|url=https://prostitution.procon.org/sourcefiles/ArmeniaCriminalCode.pdf|publisher=National Assembly of the Republic of Armenia|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=18 April 2003}}</ref> although there are known to be brothels in the capital, [[Yerevan]], and in [[Gyumri]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dudwick|first1=Nora|last2=Gomart,|first2=Elizabeth|last3=Marc|first3=Alexandre|last4=Kuehnast|first4=Kathleen|title=When things fall apart : qualitative studies of poverty in the former Soviet Union|date=2003|publisher=World Bank|location=Washington, DC|isbn=9780821350676|page=138}}</ref> According to [[UNESCO]], since the collapse of the [[Soviet Union]] in 1991, prostitution in the country has grown.<ref name="hovhannisyan">{{cite web|title=Proposed to legalize prostitution in Armenia|url=https://report.az/en/region/proposed-to-legalize-prostitution-in-armenia/|website=Report News Agency|accessdate=19 January 2018|language=en|date=14 June 2015}}</ref> There are about 5,600 women involved in [[prostitution]] in [[Armenia]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Sex workers: Population size estimate - Number, 2016 |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/dv/PivotData_2018_7_22_636678151733621264.htm |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>roughly 1,500 of them are in Yerevan.<ref name="state9">{{cite web|title=Armenia 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136018.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=11 March 2010}}</ref> However, official police figures are far lower, for example 240 in 2012.<ref name="stats" /> Police and other safety forces reportedly tolerate prostitution.<ref name="state9" /> Many women turn to prostitution due to unemployment.<ref name="iwpr">{{cite web|url=https://iwpr.net/global-voices/armenia-women-driven-prostitution|title=Armenia: Women Driven into Prostitution|publisher=|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref>
[[Child prostitution]] is a problem in the country,<ref name="iwpr2">{{cite web|url=https://iwpr.net/global-voices/armenia-child-prostitution-taboo|title=Armenia: Child Prostitution Taboo|publisher=|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref> but this is denied by the authorities.<ref name="stats" /><ref name="iwpr2" /> [[Sex trafficking]] is also a problem.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Armenia 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271135.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
==History== At the start of the 20th century, prostitution in Armenia was legal and regulated. The main objective of the regulation was to control [[sexually transmitted infection]]s.<ref name="helq">{{cite web|last1=Vardanyan|first1=Gegham|title=The Armenian sex trade - 4 - A history of prostitution in Armenia|url=http://hetq.am/eng/print/8436/|website=Hetq - News, Articles, Investigations|accessdate=19 January 2018|language=en|date=20 July 2004}}</ref>
Brothels could be opened by women over 35 years old. The brothel could not be within 150 [[sazhen]]s (320 metres) of churches, schools, and other public places. The owner must live on the premises and not engage in prostitution herself. She could take a maximum of 3/4 of the prostitutes' earnings.<ref name="helq" />
A former brothel in Teryan Street, Yerevan is still noticeable by its carved naked women on the facade.<ref name="helq" />
During majority of the soviet period, prostitution officially didn't exist. Prostitutes were sent to be "re-educated" in labour camps.<ref name="six_seven">{{cite web |url= http://www.a-z.ru/women/texts/lebina2r-3.htm |title= Кнутом или законом? |trans-title= A whip or a law? |last= Shkarovsky |first= Lebina NB |date= 1994 |website= |publisher= Progress Academy |access-date= 1 December 2017 |quote= }}</ref> It wasn't until 1987, that the Administrative Code included the prohibition of prostitution.<ref name="helq" />
==Calls for legalisation== The head of Dermatology and Infectious Diseases Scientific-Medical Center, doctor-dermatologist Samvel Hovhannisyan, was quoted as saying in June 2015: "The legalisation of prostitution in Armenia may cause a reduction of a rate of sexually transmitted diseases to 60%." The added that the "ancient profession" must be strictly controlled by the country.<ref name="hovhannisyan" />
In 2016, the ''[[Helsinki Citizens’ Assembly]]’s Vanadzor Office'' president, Artur Sakunts, called for prostitution to be legalised and regulated. He said the taxes paid by the sex workers would benefit the country, and that “Paid sex services should not be considered a punishable act; they should not be prosecuted not to be ever manageable at the hands of organized criminal groups which could make [sex workers] victims of internal trafficking.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Prostitution should be made legal in Armenia – human rights activist |url=http://www.tert.am/en/news/2016/12/16/Sakunts/2226118 |website=Tert|accessdate=19 January 2018|language=en|date=16 December 2016}}</ref>
In the run-up to the 2017 [[Armenian parliamentary election, 2017|Armenian parliamentary election]], former prime minister, [[Hrant Bagratyan]], of the [[Free Democrats (Armenia)|Free Democrats]] party said prostitution should be legalised and licensed, and taxation of their services would be positive towards the state's budget.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Martirosyan|first1=Nana|title=Free Democrats promise to legalize prostitution, while Communists are set to eradicate it|url=http://arminfo.info/full_news.php?id=24817&lang=3|website=Arminfo|accessdate=19 January 2018|language=en|date=20 March 2017}}</ref>
==Sex Trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Armenia}} Armenia is a source and, to a lesser extent, destination country for women, and children subjected to sex trafficking. Armenian women and children are subjected to sex trafficking in the [[UAE]] and [[Turkey]]. Armenian women and children are also subjected to sex trafficking within the country. [[China|Chinese]] women have been subjected to sex trafficking in Armenia. Children staying in child care institutions remain highly vulnerable to trafficking. Conflict-displaced persons, including [[Armenians in Syria|Syrian Armenians]], living in Armenia are at risk of exploitation.<ref name="state17" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://epress.am/en/2011/02/08/armenia-must-offer-women-alternative-to-prostitution-if-it-is-to-eradicate-trafficking-former-us-envoy.html|title=Armenia Must Offer Women Alternative to Prostitution if it is to Eradicate Trafficking: Evans – Epress.am|publisher=|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Armenia as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]' country.<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=Armenia 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282602.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Prostitution in the Soviet Union]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Asia in topic|Prostitution in}} {{Europe in topic|Prostitution in}}
[[Category:Prostitution by country|Armenia]] [[Category:Armenian society]] [[Category:Prostitution in Europe|Armenia]]

'''Prostitution in Guyana''' is illegal but widespread.<ref name="spl">{{cite web|title=Sexuality, Poverty and Law Programme|url=http://spl.ids.ac.uk/sexworklaw/countries|publisher=Institute of Development Studies|accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref> Prostitution law is antiquated and dates from the colonial era.<ref name="kempadoo">{{cite book|last1=Kempadoo|first1=Kamala |title=Sun, sex, and gold : tourism and sex work in the Caribbean|date=1999|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|location=Lanham [u.a.]|isbn=978-0847695164}}</ref> Law enforcement is inconsistent and sex workers report violence and abuse by the police.<ref name="spl" /><ref name="ngo" /> Many turn to prostitution for economic reasons and the lack of other job opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jemmott|first1=Shauna|title=Lack of jobs forces students into prostitution, illegal activities – UNICEF report|url=http://guyanachronicle.com/2016/09/30/lack-of-jobs-forces-students-into-prostitution-illegal-activities-unicef-report|website=Guyana Chronicle|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=30 September 2016}}</ref> Prostitution continues to receive greater public attention due to the high incidence of [[HIV/AIDS]] among prostitutes.<ref name="state1">[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/wha/119162.htm 2008 Human Rights Report: Guyana]. State.gov (2009-02-25). Retrieved on 2011-03-30.</ref> Prostitution in the country is separated into three types: "uptown", servicing affluent clients,<ref name="pellau" /> "downtown", servicing the working classes,<ref name="pellau" /> and mining sites.<ref name="state17" /> [[UNAIDS]] estimate there to be 6,00 prostitutes in the country.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sex workers: Population size estimate - Number, 2016 |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/dv/PivotData_2018_7_22_636678151733621264.htm |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
Prostitutes often rent rooms in hotels and attract clients in the hotel's bar or outside the hotel.<ref name="kempadoo2">{{cite book|last1=Kempadoo|first1=Kamala|title=Sexing the Caribbean : gender, race, and sexual labor|date=2004|publisher=Routledge|location=New York [u.a.]|isbn=978-0415935036}}</ref> Dancers in [[Lap dance|lap dancing]] and [[striptease]] establishments sometimes offer sexual services as a sideline.<ref name="kempadoo2" />
In the capital, [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]], prostitutes sometimes visit moored [[Cargo ship|freighters]], with the captain's permission, to service the crews.<ref name="kempadoo2" />
==Legal situation== Prostitution is not specifically prohibited by Guyanese law, but "common nuisance" in section 356 of the Criminal Law (Offences) Act of 1893 is interpreted to include prostitution.<ref name="spl" /> Section 357 makes it illegal to keep or manage a "common bawdy house" ([[brothel]])<ref name="spl" />
{{Quote |text='''Title 26 - Nuisances, Bawdy Houses''' : '''356.''' Everyone who commits any common nuisance which endangers the lives, safety or health of the public, or which injures the person of any individual, shall be guilty of a misdemeanour and liable to imprisonment for two years. : '''357.''' Everyone who - :: (a) keeps or manages a common bawdy house; or ::(b) keeps or manages a common ill-governed or disorderly house; :shall be guilty of a misdemeanour and liable to imprisonment for two years. |source= Criminal Law (Offences) Act (No. 18 of 1893)<ref>{{cite web|title=Laws of Guyana Chapter 8.01 Criminal Law (Offences) Act|url=https://prostitution.procon.org/sourcefiles/GuyanaCriminalOffencesAct.pdf|website=Procon|accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref> }}
The Combating Trafficking of Persons Act of 2005 prohibits all forms of trafficking and prescribes sufficiently stringent penalties ranging from three years to life imprisonment.<ref name="state17" />
===Calls for decriminalization=== In 2014, the sex workers organisation "Guyana Sex Worker Coalition" and several [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] called for prostitution to be legalised and regularization of sex work. The aims was to end discrimination and abuse towards sex workers and to give them full access to health services. The NGOs included ''Youth Challenge Guyana'' and the ''Society Against Sexual Orientation Discrimination''.<ref name="ngo">{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Kurt|title=Calls mounted for legalization of Prostitution, regularization of sex work|url=http://www.inewsguyana.com/calls-mounted-for-legalization-of-prostitution-regularization-of-sex-work/|website=iNews Guyana|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=30 January 2014}}</ref>
==Mining== There is a gold mining industry in the interior of Guyana. Women, often from Maroon and Amerindian villages, come to the area to service the gold miner's sexual needs.<ref name="pellau">{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Andrew|title=The Horniest Countries in the Caribbean|url=https://mypellau.com/2016/11/08/the-horniest-countries-in-the-caribbean/|website=Pellau Media|accessdate=22 December 2017|date=8 November 2016}}</ref> The women work in "kiamoos!, temporary structures of wood, [[zinc]] or [[tarpaulin]], that consist of a series of rooms, just big enough for a bed, where the women live and entertain clients.<ref name="kempadoo2" /> Women from the coast also travel to the mines, usually for a two or three month period.<ref name="kempadoo2" /> When there is a "shout" (significant find), the number of prostitutes around that mine increases.<ref name="kempadoo2" />
There are also [[bauxite]] and [[diamond]] mines in the country which also attract prostitutes.<ref name="kempadoo2" /> However, the downturn in the bauxite industry in the early 2000s, and resulting in less employment and spending power of the men, led to a large decline in the number if sex workers around these mines.<ref name="kempadoo2" />
There is evidence of women being trafficked to work as prostitutes at the mines<ref name="kempadoo2" />
==HIV== {{see also|HIV/AIDS in Guyana}} [[HIV]] is a problem in the country, however due to the efforts of the Guyanese government and international organisations, the situation is being controlled. The epidemic peaked in around 2006,<ref name="kaieteur">{{cite web|last1=Pearson|first1=Jeanna|title=HIV cases rising again in Guyana|url=https://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2016/05/30/hiv-cases-rising-again-in-guyana/|website=Kaieteur News|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=30 May 2016}}</ref> and in 2016 it was estimated that 1.6% of the adult population were affected.<ref>{{cite web|title=The World Factbook - HIV/AIDS - Adult Prevalence Rate|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2155.html|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]]|accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref> Amongst other measures, including education about HIV, a [[condoms]] distribution programme has been initiated.<ref name="kaieteur3">{{cite web|last1=Marks|first1=Neil|title=All those condoms? Who is using them?|url=https://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2009/03/22/all-those-condoms-who-is-using-them/|website=Kaieteur News|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=22 March 2009}}</ref> Sex workers are a high risk group.<ref name="kaieteur2">{{cite web|title=Sex workers still severely affected by HIV/AIDS|url=https://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2015/04/14/sex-workers-still-severely-affected-by-hivaids/|website=Kaieteur News|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=14 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="who" /> The incidence of HIV amongst sex workers has fallen over the years: 47% in 1997,<ref name="who">{{cite web|title=Guyana: Estimated number of people needing antiretroviral therapy (0-49 years), 2005:|url=http://www.who.int/hiv/HIVCP_GUY.pdf|publisher=[[World Health Organization]]|accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref> 27% in 2004,<ref name="who" /> 16% in 2010<ref name="unaids">{{cite web|title=Sex workers and loggers in Guyana challenge HIV together |url=http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2011/january/20110118ilosexwork/|publisher=[[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]]|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=18 January 2011}}</ref> and 6.1% in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=HIV prevalence amongst sex workers |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/vc/vcshare.html?id=d9c0ff12-f62c-44e7-8e2c-dbe736bbea30 |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=22 July 2018 |date=2016}}</ref>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Guyana}} [[Guyana]] is a source and destination country for men, women, and children subjected to [[sex trafficking]]. Women and children from Guyana, [[Brazil]], the [[Dominican Republic]], [[Suriname]], and [[Venezuela]] are subjected to sex trafficking in mining communities in the interior and urban areas. While sex trafficking occurs in interior mining communities, limited government presence in the country’s interior renders the full extent of trafficking unknown. Children are particularly vulnerable to sex trafficking. Guyanese nationals are subjected to sex trafficking in [[Jamaica]], Suriname, and other [[Caribbean]] countries. Some police officers are complicit in trafficking crimes, and corruption impedes anti-trafficking efforts.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Guyana 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271199.htm|publisher=U.S. Department of State Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons|accessdate=24 December 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
In 2017, the [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] upgraded Guyana from a Tier 2 country to [[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 1]] country following the Guyanese governments increased efforts to combat [[human trafficking]].<ref name="state17" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Khatoon|first1=Bibi|title=Guyana upgraded to Tier 1 in the Trafficking in Persons 2017 Report|url=https://newsroom.gy/2017/06/27/guyana-upgraded-to-tier-1-in-the-trafficking-in-persons-2017-report/|website=Newsroom|accessdate=24 December 2017|date=27 June 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nswp.org/members/guyana-sex-work-coalition Guyana Sex Work Coalition]
