{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Tharu
{{lang|hi|थारु}} | image = Tharu Mahila.jpg | image_caption = Tharu woman | region1 = {{flag|Nepal}} | pop1 = 1,737,470 | region2 = [[Bihar]] | pop2 = 159,939 | ref2 = {{Cite web|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/PCA/ST.html|title=A-11 Individual Scheduled Tribe Primary Census Abstract Data and its Appendix|publisher=Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner,India|last=ORGI|website=www.censusindia.gov.in|access-date=2017-11-20}} | region3 = [[Uttar Pradesh]] | pop3 = 105,291 | region4 = [[Uttarkhand]] | pop4 = 91,342 |languages = [[Tharu languages]], [[Nepali language]] |religions = [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]], traditional beliefs |related = {{hlist|[[Dhimal]]|[[Bhoksa people]]|[[Pokhariya]]|[[Ban Rawats]]}} }} The '''Tharu people''' are an [[ethnic group]] [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] to the southern foothills of the [[Himalayas]]; most of the Tharu people live in the [[Nepal]] [[Terai]].{{cite book |last=Bista |first=D. B. |author-link=Dor Bahadur Bista |year=1971 |title=People of Nepal |publisher=[[Ratna Pustak Bhandar]] |edition=second |location=Kathmandu}}{{Cite journal |last = Rajaure |first = D. P. |title = Tharus of Dang: the people and the social context |journal = Kailash |volume = 8 |issue = 3/4 |place = Kathmandu |publisher = Ratna Pustak Bhandar |year = 1981 |pages = 155–185 |url = http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/kailash/kailash_08_0304_02.pdf}}{{cite journal |author=McLean, J. |url=http://digitalcommons.macalester.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1628&context=himalaya |year=1999 |title=Conservation and the impact of relocation on the Tharus of Chitwan, Nepal |publisher=Himalayan Research Bulletin |volume=XIX |issue=2 |pages=38–44}}{{cite book |last=Guneratne |first=A. |year=2002 |title=Many tongues, one people: The making of Tharu identity in Nepal |publisher=Cornell University Press |location=Ithaca, New York |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T7FWQ6dzYZQC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} The word थारू ''thāru''{{Cite book|title=A Comparative and Etymological Dictionary of the Nepali Language|last=Turner|first=R. L.|publisher=K. Paul, Trench, Trubner|year=1931|place=London|chapter=थारु thāru|chapterurl=http://dsalsrv02.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.1:1:2790.turner}} is thought to be derived from ''[[Sthavira nikāya|sthavir]]'' meaning follower of [[Theravada]] [[buddhism]].Some Tharu groups also live in the [[India]]n Terai, foremost in [[Uttarakhand]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] and [[Bihar]].{{cite journal |author=Verma, S.C. |year=2010 |title=The eco-friendly Tharu tribe: A study in socio-cultural dynamics |journal=Journal of Asia Pacific Studies |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=177–187 |url=https://www.academia.edu/download/24194920/japsvol1no2may2010.pdf }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XK19CAAAQBAJ&pg=PA110&dq=tharu+parts+of+the+terai&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPi-idh4HTAhViJsAKHQ4YB50Q6AEIMDAE#v=onepage&q=tharu%20parts%20of%20the%20terai&f=false | title=Genes and Resistance to Disease | accessdate=31 March 2017 | pages=110}}{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LgCqCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA62&dq=tharu+eastern+terai&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwibnZr1xIHTAhWIAMAKHVNJB9YQ6AEIIDAB#v=onepage&f=false | title=Internal Conflicts: Military Perspectives | accessdate=31 March 2017 | pages=62}} The Tharus are recognized as an official [[nationality]] by the [[Government of Nepal]].{{cite book |author=Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |chapter=Tharu, Chitwania: a language of Nepal |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |location=Dallas, Texas |publisher=SIL International, online version |chapterurl=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=the}} The [[Government of India]] recognizes the Tharu people as a [[scheduled tribe]]. ==History== The origin of the Tharu people is not clear but surrounded by [[myth]]s and oral tradition. The Rana Tharus claim to be of [[Rajput]] origin and have migrated from the [[Thar Desert]] to Nepal's [[Far Western Region, Nepal|Far Western]] Terai region. Tharu people farther east claim to be descendants of the [[Śākya]] and [[Koliya]] peoples living in [[Kapilavastu (ancient city)|Kapilvastu]].Skar, H. O. (1995). Myths of origin: the Janajati Movement, local traditions, nationalism and identities in Nepal. Contributions to Nepalese Studies 22 (1): 31–42. ===Modern history (1700s-1999)=== Tharu families worked under the system of [[bonded labour]] known as [[Kamaiya]] which existed in Nepal since the 18th century; following the [[Unification of Nepal]] when members of the ruling elite families of [[Terai]] received land grants in those region and were entitled to collect revenue from those who cultivated the land.{{cite journal |author=Regmi, R. R. |year=1994 |title=Deforestation and Rural Society in the Nepalese Terai |journal=Occasional Papers in Sociology and Anthropology |volume=4 |pages=72–89 |url=https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/1325105.pdf}} In 1854, [[Jung Bahadur Rana]], the then [[Prime Minister of Nepal|Nepalese PM]], enforced the Muluki Ain (General Code) which classified both Hindus and Non-Hindus [[Caste system in Nepal|castes]] based on their habits of food and drink.Stiller, L. F. (1993). Nepal: Growth of a Nation. Human Resources Development Research Center, Kathmandu. Tharu people were categorized under "Paani Chalne Masinya Matwali" (touchable enslavable alcohol drinking group) together with several other alcohol drinking ethnic minorities.Gurung, H. (2005). Social exclusion and Maoist insurgency. Paper presented at National Dialogue Conference on ILO Convention 169 on Indigenous and Tribal Peoples, Kathmandu, 19–20 January 2005.{{cite book |author=Krauskopff, G. |year=2007 |title=Resistance and the State: Nepalese Experiences |chapter=An 'indigenous minority' in a border area: Tharu ethnic associations, NGOs, and the Nepalese state |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7DS0BAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA199&ots=3hhMAPWYpR&pg=PA199#v=onepage&f=false |pages=199–243 |editor1=Gellner, D. |publisher=Berghahn Books |edition=Revised |location=New York}} In the late 1950s, the [[World Health Organization]] supported the Nepalese government in eradicating [[malaria]] in the forests of the central Terai.{{cite journal |author=Brydon, H.W., Joshi, G. and Pradhan, S.P. |year=1961 |title=''Anopheles'' distribution and its relation to the malaria eradication programme in central Nepal |journal=Mosquito News 21|issue=2 |pages=102–105 |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/content/part/JAMCA/MN_V21_N2_P102-105.pdf}} Following the malaria eradication program using [[DDT]] in the 1960s, a large and heterogeneous non-Tharu population from the Nepali hills, [[Bhutan]], [[Sikkim]] and [[India]] settled in the region.{{Cite journal |author=Terrenato, L., Shrestha, S., Dixit, K.A., Luzzatto, L., Modiano, G., Morpurgo, G., Arese, P. |title=Decreased malaria morbidity in the Tharu and Maithil people compared to sympatric populations in Nepal |journal=Annals of Tropical Medicine and Parasitology |volume=82 |issue=1 |year=1988 |pages=1–11 |pmid=3041928}} In the western Terai, many Tharu families lost the land, which they used to cultivate, to these immigrants and were forced as [[Kamaiya]]. When the first protected areas were established in Chitwan, Tharu communities were forced to relocate from their traditional lands. They were denied any right to own land and thus forced into a situation of landlessness and poverty. When the [[Chitwan National Park]] was designated, Nepalese soldiers destroyed the villages located inside the boundary of the park, burned down houses, and beat the people who tried to plough their fields. Some threatened Tharu people at gun point to leave. ===Recent history (2000-present)=== The Government of Nepal outlawed the practice of [[bonded labour]] prevalent under the [[Kamaiya]] system in July 2000, which prohibits anyone from employing any person as a bonded labourer, and declared that the act of making one work as a bonded labourer is illegal.{{cite journal |author=Sapkota, M. |year=2014 |title=Contested Identity Politics in Nepal: Implications from Tharu Movement |journal=IOSR Journal of Humanities and Social Science |volume=19 |issue=7 |pages=16–25 |url=https://www.academia.edu/download/34103670/D019711625.pdf }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} Though democracy has been reinstated in the country, the Tharu community has called for a more [[inclusive democracy]] as they are fearful of remaining an underprivileged group.{{cite web |author=Gorkhapatra Sansthan |year=2007 |url=http://www.gorkhapatra.org.np/content.php?nid=6001 |title=Tharu community calls for inclusive democracy |publisher=The Rising Nepal |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928102719/http://www.gorkhapatra.org.np/content.php?nid=6001 |archivedate = 2007-09-28}} == Distribution == [[File:THARUNI.jpg|thumb|right|Tharu women in traditional dress]] As of 2011, the Tharu population of Nepal was censused at 1,737,470 people, or 6.6% of the total population.{{Cite book|author=Central Bureau of Statistics |title=National Population and Housing Census 2011 (National Report) |url=http://cbs.gov.np/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/National%20Report.pdf |year=2012 |publisher=Government of Nepal, National Planning Commission Secretariat, Kathmandu |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130418041642/http://cbs.gov.np/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/National%20Report.pdf |archivedate=April 18, 2013 }} In 2009, the majority of Tharu people were estimated to live in Nepal.{{Cite book | author = Central Bureau of Statistics | title = Statistical Year Book of Nepal 2009 | chapter = Chapter 1: Area and Population; Table 1.7: Population Distribution by Caste/Ethnic Groups and Sex for Nepal, 2001 | place = Kathmandu | publisher = Government of Nepal. | year = 2009}} There are several [[Endogamy|endogamous]] sub-groups of Tharu that are scattered over most of the Terai:{{cite journal |author=Krauskopff, G. |year=1995 |title=The anthropology of the Tharus: an annoted bibliography |journal=Kailash |volume = 17 |issue = 3/4 |pages=185–213 |url=http://himalaya.socanth.cam.ac.uk/collections/journals/kailash/pdf/kailash_17_0304_05.pdf}} * Rana Tharu in the [[Kailali District|Kailali]] and [[Kanchanpur District|Kanchanpur]] districts of the far western Nepal Terai; also in India, in [[Khatima|Udham Singh Nagar district]], [[Uttarakhand]] and [[Kheri district|Kheri Terai]], [[Uttar Pradesh]]. Rana Tharu claim [[Rajput]] origin.{{cite book|author= Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |chapter= Tharu, Rana: a language of Nepal |chapterurl = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=thr |location= Dallas, Texas |publisher=SIL International. Online version}} * Kathoriya Tharu mostly in [[Kailali District]] and in India{{cite book |author= Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |chapter= Tharu, Kathoriya: a language of Nepal |chapterurl = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=tkt}} * Sonha Tharu in [[Surkhet district]]{{cite book |author= Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |location= Dallas, Texas |publisher=SIL International. Online version |chapter = Sonha, a language of Nepal |chapterurl = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=soi}} * Dangaura Tharu in western Terai: [[Dang Deukhuri District|Dang-Deukhuri]], [[Banke District|Banke]], [[Bardia (Nepal)|Bardia]], Kailali and [[Kanchanpur District|Kanchanpur]] districts{{cite book|author= Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |location= Dallas, Texas |publisher=SIL International. Online version |chapter= Tharu, Dangaura: a language of Nepal |chapterurl = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=thl}} *Paschuhan (Western) Tharu in [[Rupandehi District|Rupandehi]] and [[Nawalparasi district]]s *Rautar Tharu in Rupandehi and Nawalparasi districts *Purbaha Tharu in Rupandehi and [[Kapilvastu district]]s * Aarkutwa or Chitwania Tharu in central Terai: [[Sindhuli District|Sindhuli]], [[Chitwan District|Chitwan]] and Nawalparasi districts * [[Kochila Tharu]] in eastern Terai: [[Saptari District|Saptari]], [[Bara district|Bara]], [[Parsa district|Parsa]], [[Rautahat district|Rautahat]], [[Sarlahi district|Sarlahi]], [[Mahottari district|Mahottari]] and [[Udayapur district]]s{{cite book |author= Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |location= Dallas, Texas |publisher=SIL International. Online version |chapter = Tharu, Kochila: a language of Nepal |chapterurl = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=thq }} * Danuwar in eastern Terai: [[Udayapur district|Udayapur]], [[Saptari district|Saptari]] and [[Morang district]]s.{{cite book |author= Lewis, M. P., G. F. Simons, and C. D. Fennig (eds.) |year=2014 |title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition |location= Dallas, Texas |publisher=SIL International. Online version |chapter = Dhanwar: a language of Nepal |chapterurl = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=dhw}} * [[Lampucchwa Tharu]] in [[Morang District]] * Pahalman Tharu, especially in Inner Terai such as Udayapur district of Nepal Smaller numbers of Tharu people reside in the adjacent Indian districts [[Champaran District|Champaran]] of [[Bihar]] [[States and territories of India|state]]; [[Gorakhpur district|Gorakhpur]], [[Basti district|Basti]] and [[Gonda district|Gonda]] of [[Uttar Pradesh]] state; and [[Khatima|Udham Singh Nagar]], [[Uttarakhand]] state. In 2001, Tharu people were the largest of five [[Scheduled castes and scheduled tribes|scheduled tribes]] in [[Uttarakhand]], with a population of 256,129 accounting for 33.4% of all scheduled tribes.{{cite web | url = http://www.censusindia.gov.in/Tables_Published/SCST/dh_st_uttaranchal.pdf | author = Office of the Registrar General, India (2001) | title = Uttaranchal. Data Highlights: The Scheduled Tribes. Census of India 2001 | accessdate = 2008-03-16}} In the same year, they constituted 77.4% of the total tribal population of [[Uttar Pradesh]] with a population of 83,544.{{cite web | url = http://www.censusindia.gov.in/Tables_Published/SCST/dh_st_up.pdf | author = Office of the Registrar General, India (2001) | title= Uttar Pradesh. Data Highlights: The Scheduled Tribes. Census of India 2001}} ==Culture== [[Image:Tharu village scene.jpg|frame|Tharu village near [[Bardia National Park]]]][[Image:Tharu man on our front porch.jpg|thumb|A Tharu man]] The Tharu people themselves say that they are a people of the forest. In Chitwan, they have lived in the forests for hundreds of years practicing a short fallow [[shifting cultivation]]. They plant [[rice]], [[Mustard seed|mustard]], [[Cereal|corn]] and [[lentils]], but also collect forest products such as wild fruits, vegetables, [[Herbalism|medicinal plant]]s and materials to build their houses; hunt [[deer]], [[rabbit]] and [[wild boar]], and go fishing in the rivers and oxbow lakes. The Tharus never went abroad for employment – a life that kept them isolated in their own localities.{{cite web|url= http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_19_01_02.pdf |author=Gurung, G.M. (1992). |title=Socioeconomic Network of a Terai Village: An account of the Rana Tharus of Urma-Urmi |publisher=Contributions to Nepalese Studies, Vol. 19, No. 1}} In this isolation they developed a unique culture free from the influence of adjacent India, or from the mountain groups of Nepal. The most striking aspects of their environment are the decorated rice containers, colorfully painted verandahs and outer walls of their homes using only available materials like clay, mud, dung and grass. Much of the rich design is rooted in devotional activities and passed on from one generation to the next, occasionally introducing contemporary elements such as a bus or an airplane.{{cite web |url=http://www.asianart.com/tharu |author= Meyer, K. W., Deuel, P. |year=1997 |title=The Tharu of the Tarai |publisher=Indigo Gallery, Kathmandu |accessdate=2006-12-07}} The Deukheri Tharu are known for their colorful, shell and/or feather decorated basketry, including ''ram topne'' water jug covers. {{citation needed|date=January 2018}} ===Household structure=== In the western Terai, most Rana Tharu prefer living in ''Badaghar'' called [[longhouse]]s with big families of many generations, sometimes 40-50 people. All household members pool their labor force, contribute their income, share the expenditure and use one kitchen.{{cite web|author=Lam, L. M. |year=2009 |title=Park, hill migration and changes in household livelihood systems of Rana Tharus in Far-western Nepal. |publisher=University of Adelaide |url=http://digital.library.adelaide.edu.au/dspace/bitstream/2440/58136/1/02whole.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928051025/http://digital.library.adelaide.edu.au/dspace/bitstream/2440/58136/1/02whole.pdf |archivedate=September 28, 2011 }} ===Social structure=== [[File:TharuPeople.JPG|thumb|right|Wax statues of Tharu people in [[Tharu museum]], Chitwan]] Tharus from the mid west and far west of Nepal have been practicing the ''Badghar'' system, where a ''Badghar'' is elected chief of a village or a small group of villages for a year. The election generally takes place in the month of Magh (January / February), after celebrating the ''Maghi Festival'' and after completing major farming activities. In most cases, each household in the village which engages in farming has one voting right for electing a ''Badghar''. Thus the election is based on a count of households count rather than a headcount. The role of the ''Badghar'' is to work for the welfare of the village. The ''Badghar'' direct the villagers to repair canals or streets when needed. They also oversee and manages the cultural traditions of the villages. They have an authority of punishing those who do not follow their orders or who go against the welfare of the village. Generally the ''Badghar'' has a Chaukidar to help him. With the consent of the villagers the ''Badghar'' may appoint a"Guruwa" who is the medic and chief priest of the village.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} As Tharus society is mainly involved in farming, irrigation is one of the most important aspects of the community. Tharus in western Nepal built canals that irrigate thousands of hectares of land. Hundreds of years ago, without using any sophisticated tools, they built hundreds of kilometers of irrigation canals in the ''Kailali'' and ''Bardiya districts'' of Nepal. An irrigation canal could be used by several villages. Its water and diversion works need to be managed fairly. For this purpose, the Badghars of different villages elect a person for the position of ''Chaudhary'' to manage a canal system. When needed, the ''Chaudhary'' orders the ''Badghars'' to send people to repair or build the canals. In most cases the Badghars and Chaudharis are unpaid leaders of the community. However, they are exempt from compulsory physical labor for the betterment of the society. As a token of respect, the community members may also help them in farming for a day free of cost.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ===Language=== Tharu communities in different parts of Nepal and India do not share the same language. Several speak various endemic [[Tharu language]]s. In western Nepal and adjacent parts of India, Tharus speak variants of [[Hindi]], [[Urdu]] and [[Awadhi]]. In and near central Nepal, they speak a variant of [[Bhojpuri]]. In eastern Nepal, they speak a variant of [[Maithili language|Maithili]]. More standard versions of these dialects are widely spoken by non-Tharu neighbors in the same areas so that there are no important linguistic barriers between Tharus and their neighbors. However, there are linguistic barriers between these dialects standing in the way of communication between Tharus from different regions. They also speak [[Nepali language]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Tharus already lived in the Terai before [[Proto-Indo-Europeans|Indo-Europeans]] arrived. It is unclear which language they have been speaking at that time. The only surviving pre-Indo-European language in the Terai is [[Kusunda language|Kusunda]], [[Santali language|Santhali]] further west.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} ===Cuisine=== Tharu people of Nepal have different and special food items like Bagiya{{Cite web|url=https://tharuculture.blogspot.com/2012/12/bagiya-rice-flour-dumplings-made-tharu.html|title=VOICE OF THARUS: Bagiya – the rice flour dumplings made the Tharu way|last=Chaudhary|first=Sanjib|date=2012-12-14|website=VOICE OF THARUS|access-date=2018-09-15}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thegundruk.com/tharu-cuisines-in-pictures/|title=Tharu Cuisines and Delicacies (in Pictures) - The Nepali Food Blog {{!}} theGundruk.com|date=2016-01-16|work=The Nepali Food Blog {{!}} theGundruk.com|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-US}} or Dhikri and [[Land snail#Snails as human food|ghonghi]], an edible snail collected in nearby water bodies. Dhikri is made of [[rice flour]]. The dough from the rice flour is given different shapes – many are stick-like but some are also given the shapes of birds, fish and animals. It is cooked over steam and eaten together with chutney or curry. The ghonghi are left overnight so that all the gooey material inside them comes out. Their tail end is cut so that it is easier to suck out the meat from the shell. They are boiled and later cooked like curry adding spices like [[coriander]], chilies, garlic and onions. File:Tharu Cuisine.jpg|Dried fish dish; Tharu Cuisine File:Bagya .jpg|Bagya; Tharu Cuisine File:Ghunghi.jpg|Ghunghi; Tharu Cuisine File:Tharu Beverage.jpg|Rice Wine; Tharu Cuisine File:Dhikri.jpg|Dhikari; Tharu Cuisine File:Boiled Corn.jpg|Boiled Corn with chili pickle Tharu people of India are also known for their spicy and distinct food. Dhissaphara is similar to Dhikri. ===Marriage system=== Traditionally, marriages were often arranged during the pregnancies of two women. If they gave birth to opposite sex babies, the two babies were supposed to be married if they grew up as friends. It was problematic if a boy or girl came of age and rejected their assigned fiancé(e). Finding a replacement was difficult because most girls and boys were already engaged. However this custom has been disappearing. Most Tharus now practice conventional [[Arranged marriage in India|arranged marriages]]. They also practice love marriages, inter caste marriage, marriage after courtship and eloping. ===Religion=== The spiritual beliefs and moral values of the Tharu people are closely linked to the natural environment. The [[Pantheon (gods)|pantheon]] of their gods comprises a large number of [[deities]] that live in the forest. They are asked for support before entering the forest. ==Genetics== Genetic studies on Y-DNA of Tharu populations from two villages in [[Chitwan district]] and one village in [[Morang district]] found very high presence of [[Haplogroup O-M175|Haplogroup O]] at 37% followed by [[Haplogroup H (Y-DNA)|H]] (26%), [[Haplogroup J (Y-DNA)|J]] (14%), [[Haplogroup R1a|R1a]] (9%), [[Haplogroup R2|R2]] (5%), [[Haplogroup L-M20|L]] (2%) and [[Haplogroup C-M130|C]](1%).{{cite journal|pmc=2720951 | pmid=19573232 | doi=10.1186/1471-2148-9-154 | volume=9 | title=Mitochondrial and Y-chromosome diversity of the Tharus (Nepal): a reservoir of genetic variation | year=2009 | journal=BMC Evol. Biol. | page=154 | author=Fornarino S, Pala M, Battaglia V ''et al.''}} === Resistance to malaria === The Tharu were famous for their ability to survive in the most [[malaria]]l parts of the Terai that were deadly to outsiders. In 1902, a British observer noted: "Plainsmen and paharis generally die if they sleep in the Terai before November 1 or after June 1." Others thought that the Tharu were not totally immune. Contemporary medical research comparing Tharu with other ethnic groups living nearby found an incidence of malaria nearly seven times lower among Tharu.{{Cite journal | last = Terrenato| first = L. |author2=Shrestha, S. |author3=Dixit, K. A. |author4=Luzzatto, L. |author5=Modiano, G. |author6=Morpurgo, G. |author7=Arese, P. | title = Decreased Malaria Morbidity in the Tharu People Compared to Sympatric Populations in Nepal | journal = Annals of Tropical Medicine and Parasitology | volume = 82 | issue = 1 | year = 1988| pages = 1–11 | pmid = 3041928}} The researchers believed such a large difference pointed to [[Heredity|genetic factors]] rather than behavioral or dietary differences. This was confirmed by follow-up investigation finding [[gene]]s for [[thalassemia]] in nearly all Tharu studied.{{Cite journal | authors = Modiano, G., Morpurgo, G., Terrenato, L., Novelletto, A., Di Rienzo, A., Colombo, B., Purpura, M., Marianit, M., Santachiara-Benerecetti, S., Brega, A., Dixit, K. A., Shrestha, S. L., Lania, A., Wanachiwanawin, W. and L. Luzzatto | title = Protection against Malaria Morbidity - Near Fixation of the Alpha Thalassemia Gene in a Nepalese Population | journal = American Journal of Human Genetics | volume = 48 | issue = 2 | year = 1991| pages = 390–397 | pmid = 1990845 | pmc=1683029 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1683029/pdf/ajhg00086-0217.pdf}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite journal | last = Ashokakirti | first = Bhikshu | title = Searching the Origin of Selfless Self| journal=Journal of Nepalese Studies | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | place = Kathmandu | publisher = Royal Nepal Academy}} *{{Cite book |last=Bista |first=Dor Bahadur |title=People of Nepal |place=Kathmandu |publisher=Ratna Pustak Bhandar |year=2004 |edition=9th}} *{{Cite book | last = Krauskopff | first = G. | title = Maîtres et possédés: Les rites et l'ordre social chez les Tharu (Népal) | place = Paris | publisher = Editions du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique | year = 1989 | language = French}} * {{Cite book |editor-last = Meyer |editor-first = K. | editor2-last = Deuel |editor2-first = P. | title = The Tharu Barka Naach: a rural folk art version of the Mahabharata |place = Lalitpur |publisher=Himal Books |year = 1998 |isbn = 0-9666742-0-0}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Tharu people}} *[http://www.volunteermatch.org/search/org230298.jsp Tharu Nepal - NGO promoting cultural exchange via community projects] *[https://www.pbs.org/now/media_player/player.html?id=414ss&caps=low Slide-show documentary about child slavery among Tharu] *[http://www.mercycorps.org/countries/nepal/11589 After Slavery, Unshackling Potential] *[http://educationmasters.in/general-knowledge-in-hindi-about-tharu-tribe/ Tharu tribe in Uttarakhand (in Hindi)] {{Ethnic groups in Nepal}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tharu People}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Nepal]] [[Category:Social groups of Uttar Pradesh]] [[Category:Social groups of Bihar]] [[Category:Scheduled Tribes of Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Schools of Indian painting]] [[Category:Adivasi]]

{{refimprove|date=June 2015}} [[File:Жуз.svg|thumb|right|Approximate areas occupied by the three Kazakh hordes in the early 20th century; red represents the Senior zhuz, orange represents the Middle zhuz and green represents the Junior zhuz.]] A '''''zhuz''''' ({{lang-kz|жүз|translit=júz}}, ٴجۇز, {{IPA-kk|ʒʉz|pron}}, also translated as "[[Orda (organization)|horde]]" or "[[Hundred (county division)|hundred]]") is one of the three main territorial and tribal divisions in the [[Desht-i Kypchak|Kypchak Plain]] area that covers much of the contemporary [[Kazakhstan]], and represents the main [[Kazakh tribes|tribal]] division within the ethnic group of the [[Kazakhs]].
*The '''Senior zhuz''' ({{lang-kk|Ұлы жүз|Uly júz, ۇلى ٴجۇز}}) or '''Uly zhuz''' covers territories of southern and southeastern [[Kazakhstan]], northwestern China ([[Xinjiang]]) and parts of [[Uzbekistan]]. *The '''Middle zhuz''' ({{lang-kk|Орта жүз|Orta júz, ورتا ٴجۇز}}) or '''Orta zhuz''' consists of six tribes, covering central and eastern Kazakhstan *The '''Junior zhuz''' ({{lang-kk|Кіші жүз|Kishi júz, كىشى ٴجۇز)}}) or '''Kishi zhuz''' consists of three tribes, covering western Kazakhstan.
== History == The earliest mention of the Kazakh ''júz'' or hordes dates to the 17th century. Velyaminov-Zernov (1919) believed that the division arose as a result of the capture of the important cities of [[Tashkent]], [[Turkestan (city)|Yasi]], and [[Sayram (city)|Sayram]] in 1598.<ref>Velyaminov-Zernov, "Russia, Mongolia, China in the 16th, 17th, and early 18th centuries". Vol II. Baddeley (1919, MacMillan, London). Reprint – Burt Franklin, New York. 1963 p. 59.</ref>
Some researchers argued that the ''júz'' in origin corresponded to tribal, military alliances of steppe nomads that emerged around mid-16th century after the disintegration of the [[Kazakh Khanate]]. [[Yuri Zuev]]{{year needed|date=June 2015}} argued their territorial division comprises three ecological or topographic zones, the Senior ''zhuz'' of the southern and southeastern steppe being set apart from the two other zones by [[Lake Balkhash]].
According some researchers, Kazakhs was separated in the first civil war in the Kazakh Khanate. Tribes that recognized [[Buidash Khan]] formed Senior juz. Tribes that recognized [[Togim Khan]] formed Middle juz. Tribes that recognized [[Akhmed Khan]] formed Junior juz.
According to Kazakh legends,{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} the three ''júz'' were the territorial inheritances of the three sons of the mythical founder father of the Kazakhs. In Kazakh language, ''júz'' means either "union" or "hundred".{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} <!-- there is a disagreement on the etymology, some books (which?!) in English do have the "hundred" translation, while the author of [[:ru:Жуз]] ([[:ru:User:AlefZet]]) - who is a Kazakh speaker knowledgeable about ethnography of his country) believes it is just a homonym. Another suggestion{{by whom}} derives the word from Arabic {{lang|ar|جزء}} "section, division". -->
== Senior zhuz == [[File:Kz Uysyns.gif|thumb|Ethnographic map of the Senior or Uysyn zhuz in Kazakhstan in the early 20th century, following M. S. Mukanov (1991).<ref name="Mukanov"> Муканов М. С., Этническая территория казахов в 18 – нач. 20 вв ("Ethnic territory of Kazakhs from the 18th to the beginning of the 20th century"), Almaty, 1991.</ref>]]
Historically, the Senior ''zhuz'' ({{lang-kz|Ұлы жүз|''Uly júz'', ۇلى ٴجۇز}}; {{lang-ru|Старший жуз|''Staršij žuz''}}) inhabited the northern lands of the former [[Chagatai Khanate|Chagatai Ulus]] of the [[Mongol Empire]], in the [[Ili River]] and [[Chu River]] basins, in today's South-Eastern [[Kazakhstan]] and China's [[Ili Kazakh Autonomous Prefecture]] (northern [[Xinjiang]]). It was also called ''Üysin jüz''.
The first record of the Senior ''zhuz'' dates to 1748, due to a [[Tatar]] emissary of the [[Anna of Russia|Tsaritsa]] who had been sent to the steppe to negotiate the submission of [[Abul Khair Khan]] in 1732. According to [[Nikolai Aristov]],{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} the estimated population of the Senior ''zhuz'' was about 550,000 people in the second half of the 19th century. The territory was conquered by the [[Kokand Khanate]] in 1820s, and by the [[Russian Empire]] during the 1850s to 1860s.
Kazakhstan's ruling elite, including current president [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]], former [[First Secretary]] of the [[Communist Party of Kazakhstan]] [[Dinmukhamed Konayev]], as well as famous poet [[Jambyl Jabayev]] are representatives of the Senior zhuz.
There have been several attempts to determine the exact names and nature of top level clans throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries. However, different studies created vastly different names and population numbers for the steppe clans. Generally accepted names of the first order Senior zhuz tribes or clans are:{{citation needed|date=June 2015}}
* [[Dulat]] ({{lang-kz|Дулат| ''Dýlat'', دۋلات}}) ** Janys ({{lang-kz|Жаныс,|''Janys'', جانىس}}) ** Siyqym ({{lang-kz|Сиқым| ''Sıqym'', سىيقىم}}) ** Botbay ({{lang-kz|Ботбай| ''Botbaı'', بوتباي}}) ** Shymyr ({{lang-kz|Шымыр| ''Shymyr'', شىمىر}}) * [[Jalayir]] ({{lang-kz|Жалайыр| ''Jalaıyr'', جالايىر}}) * [[Kangly|Qangly]] ({{lang-kz|Қаңлы| ''Qańly'', قاڭلى}}) * Alban ({{lang-kz|Албан| ''Alban'', البان}}) * Suwan ({{lang-kz|Суан| ''Sýan'', سۋان}}) * Sary-Uysin ({{lang-kz|Сары-үйсін|' 'Sary-úısin'', سارى-ۇيسىن}} “Yellow Uysin”) * Shapyrashty ({{lang-kz|Шапырашты| ''Shapyrashty'', شاپىراشتى}}) * Sirgeli ({{lang-kz|Сіргелі| ''Sirgeli'', سىرگەلى}}) * Oshaqty ({{lang-kz|Ошақты| ''Oshaqty'', وشاقتى}}) * Ysty ({{lang-kz|Ысты| ''Ysty'', ىستى}}) * Shanyshqyly ({{lang-kz|Шанышқылы| ''Shanyshqyly'', شانىشقىلى}})
== Middle zhuz == [[File:Kz Tribe Argyns.gif|thumb|Ethnographic map of the Senior or Uysyn zhuz in Kazakhstan in the early 20th century, following M. S. Mukanov (1991).<ref name="Mukanov"/>]] The Middle zhuz ({{lang-kz|Орта жүз|''Orta júz'', ورتا ٴجۇز}}; {{lang-ru|Средний жуз|''Srednij žuz''}}), also known as ''Arǵyn júz'', occupies the eastern lands of the former [[Golden Horde]], in central, northern and eastern Kazakhstan.
Some of Kazakhstan's famous poets and intellectuals were born in the Middle zhuz territories, including [[Abay Qunanbayuli]], [[Akhmet Baytursinuli]], [[Shokan Walikhanuli]] and [[Alikhan Bokeikhanov]].
The Middle zhuz consists of the following tribes: *[[Argyns|Argyn]] ({{lang-kk|Арғын|''Arǵyn'', ارعىن}}) *[[Khereid|Kerei]] ({{lang-kk|Керей|'Kereı'', كەرەي}}) *[[Naimans|Naiman]] ({{lang-kk|Найман|''Naıman'', نايمان}}) *[[Khongirad]] ({{lang-kk|Қоңырат|''Qońyrat'', قوڭىرات}}) *[[Kypchaks|Qypchak]] ({{lang-kk|Қыпшақ|''Qypshaq'', قىپشاق}}) *[[Taraqty]] {{lang-kk|Тарақты|''Taraqty'', تاراقتى}}) *[[Uwaq|Waq]] ({{lang-kk|Уақ|''Ýaq'', ۋاق}})
== Junior zhuz ==
The Junior or Lesser zhuz ({{lang-kz|Кіші жүз| ''Kishi júz'', كىشى ٴجۇز}}; {{lang-ru|Младший жуз| ''Mladšij žuz''}}), also known as ''Alshyn júz'', occupied the lands of the former [[Nogai Khanate]] in Western Kazakhstan. It was also called ''Alshyn júz''.
They originate from the [[Nogais]] of the [[Nogai Horde]], which once was placed in Western Kazakhstan, but in the 16th century it was defeated by the Kazakhs and the Russians and [[Nogais]] retreated to the Western part of their khanate, to the [[Kuban River]] steppes. In the 18th century they endanged inner Russian cities, so the Russian Empire allied the [[Kalmucks]] (Kalmyks) to supplant Alshyns back to the [[Urals]]. There they formed the Lesser zhuz. During Kazakh-Kalymk struggles, [[Khiva Khanate]] annexed [[Mangyshlak Peninsula]] for repelling Kalmyk raids and managed it for two centuries before Russian conquest. In the beginning of the 19th century, Kazakhs shifted some to the west, to [[Astrakhan Governorate]], forming [[Bukey Horde]] there. As the [[Kazakh SSR]] was formed with [[Bukey Horde]] as the most remoted its western part,{{Clarify|date=January 2010}} situated geographically in [[Europe]].
Historical leaders of Kazakh resistance against the Russian Empire associated with the Junior zhuz include [[Isatay Taymanuly]] ({{lang-kk|Isataı Taımanuly}}, 1791—1838) and [[Makhambet Otemisuly]] ({{lang-kk|Mahambet Ótemisuly}}, 1803/4–1846).
The Junior zhuz consisted of three groups, subdivided into clans: *Baiuly ({{lang-kk|Байұлы| ''Baıuly'', بايۇلى}}) ** Adai ({{lang-kz|Адай| ''Adaı'', اداي}}) ** [[Alasha tribe|Alasha]] ({{lang-kz|Алаша| ''Alasha'', الاشا}}) ** Baibaqty ({{lang-kz|Байбақты| ''Baıbaqty'', بايباقتى}}) ** Berish ({{lang-kz|Беріш| ''Berish'', ء بەرىش}}) ** Zhappas ({{lang-kz|Жаппас| ''Jappas'', جاپپاس}}) ** Masqar ({{lang-kz|Масқар| ''Masqar'', ماسقار}}) ** Taz ({{lang-kz|Таз| ''Taz'', تاز}}) ** Tana ({{lang-kz|Тана| ''Tana'', تانا}}) ** Esentemir ({{lang-kz|Есентемір| ''Esentemir'', ء ەسەنتەمىر}}) ** Ysyq ({{lang-kz|Ысық| ''Ysyq'', ىسىق}}) ** Qyzylqurt ({{lang-kz|Қызылқұрт| ''Qyzylqurt'', قىزىلقۇرت}}) ** Sherkesh ({{lang-kz|Шеркеш| ''Sherkesh'', شەركەش}}) *Alimuly ({{lang-kk|Әлімұлы| ''Álimuly'', ء الىمۇلى}}) ** Qarakesek ({{lang-kz|Қаракесек| ''Qarakesek'', قاراكەسەك}}) ** Qarasaqal ({{lang-kz|Қарасақал| ''Qarasaqal'', قاراساقال}}) ** Tortqara ({{lang-kz|Төртқара| ''Tórtqara'', ء تورتقارا}}) ** Kete ({{lang-kz|Кете| ''Kete'', كەتە}}) ** Shomekei ({{lang-kz|Шөмекей| ''Shómekeı'', ء شومەكەي}}) ** Shekti ({{lang-kz|Шекті| ''Shekti'', ء شەكتى}}) *Jetyru ({{lang-kk|Жетіру| ''Jetirý'', ء جەتىرۋ}}) ** Tabyn ({{lang-kz|Табын| ''Tabyn'', تابىن}}) ** Tama ({{lang-kz|Тама| ''Tama'', تاما}}) ** Kerderi ({{lang-kz|Кердері| ''Kerderi'', ء كەردەرى}}) ** Kereit ({{lang-kz|Керейт| ''Kereıt'', كەرەيت}}) ** Zhagalbaily ({{lang-kz|Жағалбайлы| ''Jaǵalbaıly'', جاعالبايلى}}) ** Telew ({{lang-kz|Телеу| ''Teleý'', تەلەۋ}}) ** Ramadan ({{lang-kz|Рамадан| ''Ramadan'', رامادان}})
